Absorb and chew on the concepts being presented, and you will have the fortune to savor what is one of the most mind-rousing realities and awe-inspiring impressions of dark fantasy pinnacles to date. This is one of those print to celluloid graphic-novelization translations that actually got it right... Watch it and enjoy!

title: Constantine Was Great. Critics Need To Enjoy Life More.
review: I liked the movie Constantine. I don't know why people don't like him but i think Keanu Reeves is awesome. The man is just trying to make a living people come on. Why do people not think he is a good actor? People who criticize actors are people who have no imagination. If they had an imagination they could see what the actor was trying to portray as well as pick up on the deeper meaning of the movie and if very talented each individual scene. Those with no imagination don't like the actors, don't like the plot, because they are too concerned in believing the only thing that is real is the world we see. You have to try and put yourselves in each of the actors places on screen and see what they are feeling according to the situation to truly enjoy a movie. An actor can't please everyone because everyone doesn't do the same things for each emotion. Example, someones happy one person may jump around in circles, another might smile a little, and a few could laugh ecstatically. An actor can't please everyone so show some respect and be open to different acting styles. You have to be open to different aspects of each individual to enjoy life. The only people who won't get this concept are the ones that have been socially challenged and haven't been around enough people to realize that one person can't please everyone and everyone has different ways of showing things so ace pt what they do as they will accept yours. In closing I would like to say next time you people go to a movie, remember what i said and "challenge" yourselves to feel what the actor is supposed to be feeling in the situation. Don't go to a movie for acting quality either, that movie was very spiritual, and had some life lessons and philosophical questions hidden in it. Open your eyes and look at things for more than what they seem, you'll be surprised how much greater your life will be. And another thing, don't criticize if you couldn't do any better. Sure Tom Hanks could talk down to Josh Hartnett, thats because he has been in the game longer and has a lot more acting experience making him better, Anyone who criticizes an actor must think they are better than the actor themselves and if so, why aren't they on the big screen. Graphics were believable but not as good as Lord of The Rings or anything. I give it a 9 Great plot, awesome acting, believable graphics. Graphics is what made it a nine. otherwise is would be a 10. Whether you like or dislike my opinion respect it. I didn't talk down to anyone who dissed Keanu Reeves I'm just saying, that you could be more open to things. Have a good one...

title: Constantine is comic book meets catechism, and THAT's entertainment!
review: Todays matinée was my first experience viewing a film in DLP. Watching the turf struggle between heaven and hell it seemed a supernatural choice of venue to witness another version of the ultimate conflict. You've seen the trailers so you know what the film is about. There have been other, less entertaining attempts to depict the rise of evil among mankind on the planet. Based on many of the web reviews I read before seeing the film, Keanu Reeves will be credited for the success or failure of the film. I won't judge the fairness of those observations, however I would like to point out that seeing Keanu in this role demonstrated his sensitivity, growth and experience. Is it monotone? or is it understated? He has matured in his craft and has developed subtleties that might be missed by those waiting for the next Matrix, or who think of him only for a reprise of 'Ted.' (Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure) The ease he with which he holds a cigarette or shuts a door; the emotional connection he shows with his costars may be lost on those waiting for the next demonstration of pyrotechnics. So lets be fair. In addition to actor assessment maybe we should judge the film on the merits of directing, writing and editing. The film is a fun, entertaining, imperfect ride. Like free will we have a choice once we buy the ticket: focus on the negative and leave the theater or stay have fun enjoying the sins of imperfection.

title: Don't Blame Keanu
review:
I just saw the sneak preview for this movie last night at UCSD. The movie, in my opinion, is better than all the bad rap it's going to get. You KNOW it's going to get a lot of whiny critics poking at stuff they honestly can't expect a movie like this to have.

First, acting: Keanu does an OK job at being a chain-smoking SOB, and they probably could have cast someone better-- BUT he makes the character work. If you've read the comics your probably going to be disappointed, but if you just sit back and watch him do his weird little thing he actually isn't that bad. As expected Rachel Weiss's performance exceeds his in quality, but even her performance is dwarfed by the glorious Tilda Swinton who plays (I guess "the") angel Gabriel. Very cool role, VERY cool actress. Good times.

The atmosphere of the movie is... well, just about what you'd expect a movie about demons and exorcisms to be: dark, rainy, and dreary. Kind of odd considering they chose to set the movie in Los Angeles, which, while still a sh*t hole, is pretty damn sunny and dry. PROPS for their portrayal of hell, however, because I think they did a pretty damn good job with that. Probably should have showed more suffering and torment down there, but that's why I think someone needs to make a big-screen adaptation of "The Inferno."

Now for the plot. I actually had LOW expectations for the plot, but it wasn't as transparent as I thought. It kinda does a lot of things at once, so when they pull it all together your like "oh, okay, I could see that". Not exactly any surprises, but I wasn't bored. I'm sure they could have been more faithful to the comic, which relied a lot more on Constantine's wit than this one, but like I said before, they work with what they have. As far as endings go... well I've seen worse. I enjoyed the way they ended it and I also liked how the plot and resolution of the movie relied a lot on character interactions rather than random action scenes.

Speaking of action scenes... yea, they're cool. But you've seen a million like them before. Just enjoy what they give you and don't ask for more, this isn't Crouching Tiger or The Matrix (forgive me for using those two movies in the same sentence).

Other things: I actually enjoyed the movie's portrayal of both demons and angels, and found that the angles actually got the better end of the deal in this CG round compared to the hoaky-looking demons (flat heads? c'mon). True, the demons get more camera time, but you understand. Also, the movie didn't overuse it's characters and didn't beg for a sequel, though I'm sure someone at Warner Bros will mention it someday. Overall it was a lot of fun and probably worth the price of admission, but if your one of those whiny movie watchers who are never satisfied with a super-hyped action film, your not going to find this one any more attractive in the end.

title: Great film go see it
review: Just seen the film and its good, not the be all and end all or award winner but much better than many other films made theses days, if you read the comic you will rip the film apart but changes need to be made for big screen films(Xmen-dress up changed/The crow-skull cowboy taken out/Blade-dress up changed)be it the look or something they feel is to deep or people will not get, all comic book films will never please everyone and even more so if you read them week in week out, if you have not picked up Hellblazer yet then by all means do but it might be best you see film first so you don't sit there saying "that ain't right, hey he should be" and so on, the acting is fine and yes Mr Matrix himself is as he always is but he fits these kind of films and seeing as he is bankable they will use him for films such as this and Matrix kind for years. Just sit down tune in leave the comic at the front door and enjoy.

title: Constantine - 2 Thumbs Up
review: I wasn't too sure about seeing this movie or not, but I did some online research first to see what people were saying about the film. Surprisingly a lot of people were hyped about seeing it. So I decided to see the film myself. It was such a great film!!! Awesome animation. But the only problem was that I can really only think of Keanu as "The One" character. And you know I went home that night to review it on moviefone because earlier I saw review was available, so this movie was worth while and I'd see it again. I heard there was also a ending credits "cutouts", I'm not sure, I walked out too soon. If I were to see it again, I'd certainly go without any hesitation. "See it again!"

title: One of the best movies I've seen in a long time
review:
Just to let you all know, I'm not a comic book reader, and I've never even heard of hellblazer before this movie came out. So I'm not about to make any comparisons between the movie and the comic, and whine abt details that waren't 100% accurately portrayed on-screen like some geek who has no life.

This was a great movie, plain and simple. The effects were spectacular but not overdone like in Blade, where you're completely distracted by how awful the CGI looks. In Constantine, they used it well, and whatever CGI was used, served the story well.

Keanu was all right as well. I'm sick to death of pple who bash his acting skills. Look, I know he's not going to win any acting awards from this movie, but he's not that bad either. (Plus, he looks really hot in that shirt/tie and long black jacket. I'm not the only one either. The demon Balthazar and Lucifer could hardly keep their hands and tongues off Keanu in their scenes together.) Anyway, you won't be bored or left fidgeting in your seat because the movie starts off right in the middle of action, where a young girl is being possessed exorcist-style, and continues at a pretty even pace afterwards. There were some lagging moments but if you pay attention, those talky bits are quite important to the storyline and how it all unfolds in the end.

Don't listen to those people who bash this great movie outright. Watch the movie and decide for yourself. You won't regret it.

title: When a movie is more well known than the actual Constantine the Great smh
review: I am more upset because I am trying to do a paper and I keep seeing stuff on this movie instead of the actual Constantine. But I have tried watching this movie a few years ago and could not watch it way too cheesy.

title: This movie was awful
review: When I first heard about this movie, I didn't expect much. I figured it would be a typical action movie, with little plot and lots of fighting. This was not the case at all. Constantine was one of the most boring movies I have ever seen. On top of that, it was very preachy, and I personally enjoy thinking for myself. The ending made no sense, as one of God's top angels was trying to end the world without God's consent. Also, fire destroyed every demon that they encountered, so even when the perfect opportunity for a fight scene arrived, nothing happened. I honestly fell asleep several times while watching this piece of tripe. I recommend it to no one.

title: The Real Constantine Review
review: I don't know what it is that everyone sees Keanu Reeves as the worst actor in the world. There are worst out there people! I read the review for his most recient move titled 'Constatine' and that person said that they didn't know much about the comic. In the 'Hellblazer' books, John Constantine is just this dull, average guy who just dabbles in satanism and witchcraft to save the day. His personality is also one of a kind due to Constantine caring more for his own survival than everyone around him. I think the director made a good choice to make Keanu Reeves John Constantine and I'm sticking to my words. For some advise, next time anyone is going to see a movie that is based off of a novel or a comic book, read it first or get yourself familiar with it before you say the movie sucked.

title: Constantine
review:
Please readers, if you haven't seen the movie 'Constantine' Please do not read any further, as this contains 'Spoilers' and I don't want to ruin it for you...Thank ever so much...Canapril

I think that director Francis Lawrence and superstar Keanu Reeves did one fine job out of this movie..for what they had to work with, that being a comic book character. Yes, I have to agree that Francis Lawrence's directional debut is stunning and that it was really well done. Keanu Reeves acted exactly the way that the character John Constantine really is like especially attitude wise, how he would react to any situation if you've ever followed any of the Hellblazer comics or novel's story. Keanu Reeves' acting is not thought of by his fans, as him having a trademark of wooden demeanor..that terminology was once started by someone...people thought it to be intelligently said, so writers kept using it. Keanu Reeves is indeed an action hero to many, a romantic figure to millions of woman and a hero to many young boys. His acting of the character John Constantine was exactly as it should have been. Constantine, knew he was dying of cancer, he was definitely thinking of trying to get in good with the man upstairs, to earn his way into heaven by doing good deeds...he hated that he had this gift, to be able to see half breeds and demons and he only thought of it as being a curse. He was far from being stoical, he was down right pre-occupied with trying to get to all of those demons and put them where they belonged and he was angry with this gift-curse..he hated being the way he was and knew he had to do good deeds, because he didn't want to go to hell after he dies where half of the people there, were those that he had sent back there. Yes, he sulked and he pondered heavily about the whole thing and searched for ways to get rid of them, even going back to hell in search of Angela's sister Isabelle and he was really emotional while trying to exorcise Angela by the pool and also in his apartment with the tub and water scene. He definitely was not coming across as bemused...he was always on the alert to try to make things right, the terrible things he could see and hear and he had had enough, even throwing the Good Book on the floor in Gabriel's Library den. Thats Emotions and Thats Anger!

Each to his or her own opinions... speaking of emotions, how about when you see his hatred for the demon soldier in the little girl? His disgust for the demon within her...What is that, if not emotions? there were many, too numerous to mention.... but I got a super great charge out of Keanu, when he was thinking of whether or not Rachael should keep her clothes on for the bathtub scene...he truly was giving it some heavy duty thought..even if it was only for a few seconds... it was... Totally Funny!

If you try watching it more than once (I've seen it 4 times)....guaranteed you'll see all the parts you've missed and were not aware of the first time around...you'll get an altogether different perspective on the whole film and you'll see and hear more than you expected or that you did the first time viewing.

Keanu Reeves does not fail in his acting of the character Constantine and neither does the film. If you indeed watched the whole film, you would have known that Constantine did not fail, the son of Satan doesn't survive in Angela, because Constantine exorcised it, so John Constantine gets his wish, he gets to live, because Satan removed the cancer from his lungs. Satan also loses as daybreak comes in and Satan can't be present in the light of God and Satan realizes that John Constantine made a genuine, sincere sacrifice, so Constantine lives! Its a Supernatural Mystery Thriller...Constantine (Keanu) was a fine exorcist and knew how to rid LA area of all these half demons and he was doing a lot of good but his good deed was only recognized by Satan that John Constantine, finally made a sacrifice and that's how Satan loss.

Keanu Reeves is one heck of a fine actor, he is very versatile and flexible in all the roles that he has played throughout the years and at least he tries different roles. Just because he acts a part, that a director wants him to do or performs a certain way, doesn't mean that the man Keanu Reeves is like this at all. He's an Actor and he did a fine job on this one and so did the director and the rest of the cast. There's a saying that goes with Keanu Reeves, you either like him or you don't and I like this actor, cause he's not afraid to try different roles and he's not conceded like many out there, he's down to earth and very polite and he takes time for his fans and the public, so big deal ..he likes his private life private..wouldn't't you? Yes, save your money..and then go buy the DVD and watch it more than once, its totally different each time..by the way after the credit write-ups, there is another scene..or did you stay long enough to watch it?

Note: Constantine is out now on video. I work at a Video Store, I can tell you first hand that 'Constantine' is being rented a lot and sold often. Maybe you didn't like it, but many people do.

title: Demon Hunter C
review:
Well, there goes the world again, for the End of Days is nearing. I must admit that I'm not a real fan of 'Angels versus demons' of 'God versus Lucifer' films, but I thought that the comic book based Constantine could bring a nice twist to the oh so familiar story. Sometimes it even does. The film is well filmed and at times it is really surprising. What the film lacks though is depth and excitement. The film is not very gripping and I think that is because the lead character (played by Keanu Reeves) is not gripping enough. Whether this is a failure of the script or Keanu I can't really say, since I don't know the comics but I admit I felt little connection with our hero. I could connect much better with Angela (Rachel Weisz) and I think she acted very well. She was about the only one who brought some feeling into this. Sure Keanu had some funny lines and his cynical ways were pretty good most of the time, but his character and Weisz's didn't seem to connect at all (on any level). Another minor 'bug' in my mind is that the bad guys weren't well-cast either. They just weren't scary in any way...it always seemed that while Constantine was just a man and they were demon's they couldn't do him one bit of harm. Silly...but an explanation for the lack of thrills in this one. In the beginning I expected something like The Crow, Dracula or Vampire Hunter D and in the end I got 'The Exorcist on the road' or...well you've read the summary...

somewhere between 6,5 and 6,75 out of 10 (with a small 7 given upon voting)

title: Bad, bad film.
review:
Terrible action/horror movie that puts on a lot of hot air but lacks a lot of brains and substance to pull off the story its trying to tell. Keanu Reeves was just the wrong man for the job and his performance is that bad. You just want to smash his faces of the people who though that he was right for this kind of role. You just don't take him seriously and you end up laughing at him more than being intrigue by his character. His co-star Rachel Weisz not only has a more interesting character than he does but is 100 times more the actor he could ever hope to be. She not only gives the film's best performance (a performance that has more life and complexity than the film itself) but is the films only redeeming quality. You actually want to spend more time with her character and pick her brain on the life she have lived and the sister she has forgotten instead of the mindless dribble that the film because after the second act. Her story would have made a much better and scarier horror movie but of course this is a Keanu Reeves movie, and we have to suffer with a script and a director who will cater to his limited needs as an actor. The director has some talent with visuals but he has no idea on how to put a actual film together and the screenplay is so unfocused that you really have no idea on what is going on from time to time.

Worth a look for Weisz's efforts but don't hold out hope for a film as good as she was

title: A total disaster
review: It's with a certain glee that I am submitting my opinion on this "movie". Once in a while comes a movie that is so atrociously bad that it becomes fun to hate. CONSTANTINE is one of these movies. It's easily (too easily) the worst movie of 2005, but it's also a strong contender for the worst movie of the last 5 years. Before you dismiss me as a Keanu Reeves hater, know that I love (and own on DVD) the full Matrix trilogy (yes, even Revolutions) and My Own Private Idaho, definitely his best role to date. I'm also a big horror movie fan. So all in all I was really excited when I went to see that film. The trailer was awesome, I couldn't wait! The film starts well, I mean the first 5 to 10 minutes. It's all downhill from there, culminating in the most unexciting climax of all time, with Peter Stormare as the most ridiculous and non-threatening Satan ever. Keanu Reeves kind of proves his naysayers right by offering one of his most awful and wooden performances ever, on a par with his "work" in Brad Stoker's Dracula, but worse, as in that movie he didn't have such a long time on screen. Here, he's there constantly, non-playing. Ewww. Rachel Weisz is good (as always), but not enough to save the film. I lost any interest whatsoever after half an hour, and the only reason I didn't leave the theater was that I didn't want to be rude to my mate, who I had dragged to see this. I thought maybe he was enjoying it. However, when the stupid and absolutely unexciting climax happened, I turned to him and asked "Are you enjoying this?" He replied "Are you kidding??" "Should we leave then?" did I ask... "It's almost over, we might as well stay". Well we shouldn't have. The ending was as bad as the rest of the movie. Oh, for those of you who think "it might not be fantastic, but I'll watch it for the special effects"... a word of warning: the CGI looks like a cheap video game, absolutely not realistic. Rent it if you must, but don't make a blind buy, you will regret it bitterly!

title: Why this movie condemned itself to hell
review:
Okay, so here's my typically film-student critique of this movie. I'm not going to just bash it without giving good examples and saying what I would've done to change it if only I'd written the damned screenplay.

Problem # 1: Tone. It's a movie about Heaven and Hell and demons on earth and the apocalypse. A good director and writer could've really done this movie justice by making it darker, excluding the cute, witty one liners and quirks and going for the R-rated brutality of its theme. I don't totally blame the director for this: there were some interesting moments I give him credit for and some great mise-en-scene choices (devil in a white suit--classic); a little too much CGI for my taste and not enough left to the imagination, but I think he did his best, to no avail. My point is, a perfectly good excuse to use the darker, more serious tone that would've suited this concept was squandered, and my two hours were bruised because of it.

Problem #2 (a more obvious problem): wasted time on too many characters and repeated actions. This movie could've saved precious time by combining characters--thereby allowing us to understand and get to know them better--and by not having 25 trips to hell and 7 exorcisms (don't say "Nuh uh"--I'm exaggerating). Here's what I mean by combining characters: the priest, the bowling alley guy and the annoying sidekick all could've been made into one character, the "sidekick/researcher" character who does all the things these three do for the plot without weighing it down with three separate characters. Also, Balthazar and Gabriel could've been combined to form a singular "tangible threat" character; Gabriel could've easily done all the things Balthazar did without having to splinter into two separate characters. Why wasn't this done to prevent the chaos of too many meaningless flat characters with five-minute parts and deaths that came before you could even give a crap about them? Because of Problem # 3...

Which is this: Constantine shouldn't have been an adaptation of the comic. It should've been based on the comic. What's the difference? It's the difference between O Brother Where Art Thou (a film based on Homer's Odyssey) and Troy (a poor adaptation of Homer's Iliad). A film based on a book or comic has more creative freedom to know which characters or events do or don't work for the film, to make changes, to deviate. The screenwriter made the mistake of thinking he had to adapt this comic to film, and thereby assuming that this meant he had to squeeze an entire comic book series and all its coolest characters into a 2-hour frame, necessity and plot be damned.

That said, I'm not totally mad at this movie. Keanu gave one of his biggest efforts at acting ever (some will snort that that isn't saying much). Plus, every time I see Djimon Honsou smile I have this Pavlovian response that makes me say "I like him". And Peter Stormare made the most original devil I've seen in a while, with his wonderfully creepy mannerisms and discomfiting presence (funny thing: the first time I saw him in Fargo in a scene after he kills a cop, I said "That man is the devil--in a real good way"). So to wrap it up, here's my solution: some writers need a license to adapt comic books. Then maybe we'd have more Sin City's and Crow's and less Constantine's.

title: Not a perfect balance, but entertaining nonetheless
review:
Constantine tells the story of John Constantine (Reeves), an anti-hero who plays the role of some sort of guardian, maintaining "the balance" between the angels of Heaven and the demons of Hell in an action movie that is guilty of trying too hard to be stylish, slowing down what is otherwise an enjoyable action flick.

The acting in Constantine is one thing that can't be faulted. Reeves, with his his hushed tones and anti-heroic mannerisms, puts in a decent performance, with his cruel but amusing character endearing the audience just enough to carry the film along. Weisz is similarly effective, as are the rest of the solid yet unspectacular supporting cast.

For the most part, the CGI is pretty smooth too; it isn't exactly understated but it's not overused. However, I do have a problem with the needless art school camera angles and turns of pace. The introduction of Keanu is shot with such needless...lack of style. We get a slow motion shot of a cigarette dropped from the window, to the floor, we get a birds eye view of him exit a cab, and we are treated to an exorcism from the point of view of his cigarette, for no real reason. The overuse of the slow motion irritates me the most. Keanu's first descent into hell is a prime example of this; it takes poor Rachel something like thirty seconds to close the door, and this cheap attempt to play off the success of bullet-time sucks the pace out of what would otherwise be an enjoyable action movie.

The plot isn't overly confusing, and it explains everything neatly enough. It could have perhaps played up the theology a bit more, but then it wouldn't really have been an action film anymore. Overall, it's good enough to be worth a look but sometimes feels a bit slow. Don't expect a classic and you shouldn't be too disappointed.

title: pretty good, for a sci-fi
review: i'm actually surprised to find that the theatrical trailer makes this movie seem good, and when i saw the movie, it actually was. i'm a big sci-fi fan, so movies like this are my life. lol my sis saw this movie and said that she couldn't sleep that night. it's cuz she's not use to watching movie's like this. if you've seen the previews, they show Constantine does stuff like 'exorcisms', and my sis is afraid of watching 'the exorcist' so let's just say she freaked. me, on the other hand, i enjoyed this movie very much, and couldn't find out why anyone would be scared of it. it had it's jumpy moments of course, but not scary. a lot of stuff is very confusing.. i get the main story about the movie, but not the little things.. i can't really say, but like why things happen, they never really explain, they expect you to be on the same page with what's going on. don't know how to explain that, but i don't want to give out any spoilers. :) i loved how Rachel weisz acted.. an excellent job. she made everything seem like it was actually happening. keanu reeves did good too. i've seen him in matrix and speed, so of course you know he acts good, you expect that from him, but Rachel weisz we don't really know, except from the mummy. coming from the mummy to doing a movie like this, i thought she wouldn't be up to the hype, but she surprised me. so i was impressed. i would give this movie a 10, but as i said before some things i didn't understand, plus it didn't end like i wanted it too... lol. but if you're into sci-fi movies (and movies with people having abilities you wish you had lol) well this is the movie for you. i recommend you see it during the day, so it wouldn't be so crowded, because the audience could ruin the movie for you. a lot of people laughed at parts that i didn't think were funny, someone's cell phone rang, i mean it was a mess, but i still kept my eyes glued to the screen. if you don't want people to ruin the movie for you, i suggest you just wait till it comes out on DVD.. hope this comment helps

title: Constantine haters need to shut it
review: I, for one, am sick and tired of hearing all the negative press about Constantine, or Keanu Reeves' 'lack' of talent. I mean, true, he's no Sidney Poiter but who is? That and the fact that Reeves is a good, solid actor in his own right. The movie is a solid production that relies on special effects and character interaction to get the job done. It does admirably. All these people out here bashing this movie that have seen it, need to see it again and make sure that they aren't getting mad at the previews to other movies. I understand that everyone has their own opinion but when a movie opens with 11 million dollars in the FIRST DAY has something to say- with an exclaimation mark. I have no doubt that this movie will topple the 100 million mark easily. (lord knows I'm gonna go see it a few more times)I mean, I respect that people are not going to like this movie, but... don't cram the fact that 'it sucks' down my throat.

title: Funny Review
review:
"The Singapore Health Promotion Board has found the perfect spokesperson for its anti-smoking campaign  and it's none other than Keanu Reeves in the role of the reluctant anti-hero cum walking chimney John Constantine.

In between exorcism rites and fight-fests with renegade demons, the cancer-stricken and hard-drinking Constantine continues to flip his Zippo with panache, fire up the fags and down cough suppressants as we would Ribena.

...

The only grouse that gay audiences may have with Constantine lies in its portrayal of demons as homosexual or bisexual: Balthazar snarls in Constantine's face and declares him to be "finger lickin' good" while the white-clad Lucifer (Fargo's Peter Stormare) goes one step further by playing footsie with Constantine's inner thigh and giving him a good tongue wash.

Then again, with Keanu Reeves as the shirt-and-tie walking fetish Constantine  anyone homosexual, bisexual, heterosexual or remotely sexual would be hard-pressed not to feel weak in the knees  especially when confronted with his bubble butt and a gratuitous scene of him tearing off his shirt to expose his defined abs."

title: An Original Movie Worth Going To See!
review: I have to say I went to this movie not seeing any previews, not knowing a thing about the movie, and more importantly, I was not looking forward to seeing this movie. I am glad I went, as this is a movie that left me wanting to see more. There is a not as much action as one would hope, but the special effects, the plot, and the ending was wonderful. This movie does have it's comedy here and there, which surprised me, but it had that punchline just where it deserved it. It seems like Keanu has been doing movies that are simply original, and that is what makes this movie great! A great deal of the actors are from Europe, so their accents add to their roles superbly.

title: Naysayers
review: Keanu is GREAT in this movie. He fights, and kicks butt like ain't nobodies business. I can't believe all you naysayers out there are dissing him. It takes a lot of balls seeming how I bet you couldn't do half as good of a performance as he did. It really blows that you guys make fun of someone because he does a better job at something than you could ever do in this lifetime or the next... The movie is very noteworthy and Keanu's performance convinced me. I don't understand why everyone is bagging on him and the movie. I personally believe that this is one of Keanu's best performances since Speed and Sweet November.

title: I liked it a lot
review:
Although a lot of people have trashed this movie, I really thoroughly enjoyed it. Keanu may not be the best actor in the world, but as this dark character involved in the supernatural I found him to do a great job. The plot, I thought, was pretty sound. Many others have said it leaves out all background story of other characters involved, and it does so for Chaz (Shia LaBeouf) and Beeman (Max Baker), but it's not very difficult to figure out background for some of the other characters. It's not exactly obvious or evident how Constatine comes to be who and what he is throughout the movie in his life, but it's pretty unimportant.

I didn't think the special effects were bad, as not all that many or extensive effects were used, and thought the wings on each of the "half-breed Angels" were totally awesome. I liked the minimal use of specific physical weapons and more the use of religious icons and symbols.

This may not be the deepest movie of the year, as it's pretty simple and surface, but I thought it was enjoyable, fun, interesting, had enough action to keep me interested without making it what I would call a purely action movie. I enjoyed it enough to see it twice opening weekend, and I'd recommend it to most everyone I know.

title: Extremely enjoyable.
review:
I walked out of the theatre shocked. I had been expecting to be disappointed, but I honestly went through most of the film with my mouth hanging open - absolutely blindsided by the fact that this film... actually... doesn't suck.

Now, if you're one of those hard core comic book fans who just refuses to accept the idea of Keanu Reeves in this part, then fine, nothing is going to keep you from hating this movie. The fact was, however, that Keanu didn't do half-bad job. His dry, dark, emotionless visage works well within the realms of film noir (far better than I expected) and damn, if he doesn't pull off cancerous well.

All of the other actors were exceptional - although I didn't hear a lot of what Gavin Rossdale was saying because my companion couldn't stop laughing and going "IT'S BUSH!" over and over (to be fair, I WAS thinking this).

The effects, cinematography, and editing were fantastic. Some were mind-blowing. Excellent movie all around.

title: Every aspect is well done
review: From the first frame until the last, Constantine entertains. The special effects are well used and not overblown. The screenplay is very witty and the visuals compliment it well (if you are very observant of the scenes you will be awarded with some really hilarious subtle details). The film is just as entertaining as a summer blockbuster, has the intelligence of a thinking man's thriller, and has more scares (well engineered ones at that)than any of these schlocky horror flicks of the recent months (Boogeyman, the Grudge, etc.) The imagery is also very intense (a fight scene near the end in a Hospital is simply jaw dropping and is worth the price of admission alone.) The smaller roles, Midnight, Satan, Balthazar (Bush's Rossdale takes quite an impressive turn here), and Gabriel steal the scenes they are in easily (Peter Stormare's Satan in particular, one of the best incarnations of the Devil in cinema history). Rachel Weisz is solid, as is Keanu. A lot of people don't like Keanu because he lacks the seriousness of someone like like Clive Owen or Sean Penn. Well luckily, the screenplay isn't all too serious and Reeves is just as much fun to watch as the anti-hero as he was in Speed or the Matrix. I can't imagine why this film is getting as low marks as it is, even if people find Reeves unwatchable the story is solid as is the visuals. Go see Constantine and decide for yourself.

title: Great movie
review: This movie was great. I really love Keanu Reeves and his acting style is hard to like but he shines in this role. Rachel Weisz and Tilda Swinton are also great as always. The effects are fabulous and the camera work is different, and that's a good thing. Don't get me wrong, this movie is an effect party with great optic, atmosphere and actors. The story isn't brilliant or new but that really doesn't matter at all. If you are open minded and like a movie about angels, demons and the devil than watch this one and have good dirty fun!!! And all you Keanu haters out there: you don't have to like him so could you please be so kind and avoid his movies so I don't have to read your never changing opinion about him anymore. Constantine is a great comic book movie and I can really recommend it to everyone who gives new directors with new visions a chance.

title: For once, Keanu acts
review:
It was godsend that Keanu Reeves actually acts in the movie. For once, or in many occasions as the cynical John Constantine, he exhibited more than the usual five facial expressions he had in all of his previous outings - frown, deeper frown, even deeper frown, awkward happiness, painful scornful look.

So for that alone, Constantine deserves a good rating. The apocalyptic feel of the movie is not unlike that of many horror/thriller movies - 28 Days Later, 12 Monkeys - and it worked pretty well with the wry humor of the title character. The wit and plot may not be as sharp as the comic, but I think it was good enough for a movie. Definitely worth the ticket price. (Rachel Weisz wet in her undergarments was a bonus.) Bet there is going to be a sequel.

title: my notes
review: Pretty terrible. not my kinda movie. lots of madness and made up stuff your supposed to care about. some cool scenes and creativeness. but overall sucky (2 viewings)

title: Outside of the game performances of Rachel Weisz and Djimon Hounsou, there is nothing here to see.
review: Terrible adaptation of the great comic book "Hellblazer" is nothing short of a smack in the face of the fans of the comic book with a terrible and down right crude performance by Keanu Reeves, who makes a joke out of one of the most beloved cult comic book characters made in the last twenty years. His performance is bad to the point of wanting to throw something at the screen just out of sheer rage. The screenplay is a joke and the dialog rages from bad to much worse as the movie progresses and the special effects are so badly done that the monsters would have been better off if they were puppets instead. Some of the actors in the film are better than the film itself with great performances by Rachel Weisz, who gives the only good performance this movie really has and Djimon Hounsou, who is the only actor who does his comic book character any justice. Despite Weisz and Hounsou however, the movie is a bad and not even their talents could have saved it.

title: Terrible
review:
This is one of the worst comic book adaptations into a film ever made, along with "Watchmen" and "Batman & Robin". Hellblazer was an intriguing,brilliant comic book. "Constantine", on the other side is just boring, stupid and muddled film, with ugly visuals and terrible performances. Keanu Reeves just repeats his role of "Neo" in this inane, poorly made film, without any thrill or interesting element. It fails both as an action film and as a horror film. "Constantine" has a horrible plot, horrible performances and horrible visuals. And it has horrible music too. Don't waste your time with this inane movie, read the comic "Hellblazer" instead.

This film doesn't have any single redeeming value.

0/10

title: Hopeless movie in more ways then one
review:
﻿I can only say that I have regretted watching a film and wished I had never seen it only a few times in my life. This is definitely one of those times. What on God's green earth were they thinking when they green lighted this project? Up front I have to admit I am an evangelical Christian in Seminary preparing for ministry, so I am a little slanted. But hear me out.

I enjoy watching films because in part they can tell you volumes about the attitudes and feelings people have about faith and God. This looked like it would be an interesting film to get a pulse for the spiritual attitude of America. Right from the trailer I knew it would tackle some pretty big questions. But I am afraid this film speaks volumes of the hopelessness people feel. I came away depressed and saddened. Evil is ever present, close at hand and God is no where to be found. Worse still man is left to fight this great evil on his own. If it is truly as bad as the movie portrays why do any of us stick around to endure? What hope do we have the next life will be any better? All of us I believe desire a relationship with God why can't we portray that on film instead of laws and rules? It would at least make us feel better wouldn't it? I think this film got at least one think right about man's spiritual condition (though I seriously doubt it was intentional), man is without any hope separated from a God who intervenes in our lives.

OK spiritual questioning over. I gave this film a 3 instead of a 1 because it is visually stunning. It truly captures something of the horror I personally believe hell must be like. The other computer effects were equally dramatic and terrifying. But the more I think about the plot and character development the more this film disappoints me. Why does Satan's son choose this time to come out onto the world? Why would Lucifer not want his son to reign death and destruction on the world. If this is truly a dualistic world why do we see a predominance of demon half breads with out angelic ones being just as prevalent? Or better yet how are half breeds even created if there is no crossing over between plains? If in heaven there are more chapters in the Bible how do people on earth know about it? The main item driving this film is that the truce, the balance is being broken. Why then does this balance seem so easy to break and why does it only seem to get broken one way (ie from the demonic side)? This film in my opinion simply fails to be consistent in terms of plot and characters. Rules are broken for the sake of story way to easy and way to often.

title: Awesome Movie
review:
This movie is awesome. The characters are great, and there isn't anyone character who doesn't measure up. The classic battle between good and evil, except what this movie/comic story does is introduces the gray. That gray is John Constantine, works for heaven, but is damned to hell. Plus the guy knows it, that makes it worse for him. How can you be anything but cynical when you are working your hardest to go to heaven, but know your going to hell. Keanu plays the role perfectly. A lot of people might be confused with the movie, but really there isn't much too it. Take a step back, try not to think too hard and enjoy the ride. It is all there, and if you don't get it the first time, it will come.

Who cares if you think the CG sucks, the new Star Wars has great CG but, the character development just isn't there. You can tell the Actors are enjoying their roles, as the cast is absolutely brilliant. This movie isn't for everyone, but if you enjoyed Devils Advocate, or movies like Ninth Gate & Stigmata, this one is for you. If you are a big Will Smith fan, and favorite movie is ranked up there with 2 fast 2 furious, maybe you should avoid this one and stick with movies that are pure action, no thought required. Hey that formula seems to work, cause they keep getting produced. However, since spider man became a hit and every comic book from the green lantern to Straczynski's epics Rising Stars and midnight nation have had movie rights bought up, maybe this is the new trend and formula in movies. At least they are using stories that are entertaining.. Lets just hope they get them right, too bad about daredevil and elektra.

title: Absolutely amazing movie.
review:
This movie couldn't have been better.Keanu is and has been a very good actor.His portrayal of constantine was perfect.The nonchalance and morbid character suited him.It was great. Gavin Rossdale played a perfect role as well.I loved just how sly he was.God he was good at playing an influencer.Rachel Weisz played a good part as well.She was very strong..yet somehow retained that fragile part of her.Djimon Hounsou very good part. Very creepy.The scene in his club was very well done.Tilda Swinton well what can i say... gabriel never looked so good. There is something about an angel telling you that you are fucked that kind of kills your hope at the time. :D Satan couldn't have been better cast Peter Stormare is a great actor and i don't think they could have done better.

I gave this movie a 10 because it was unique and well done. The visuals were amazing.This will be a favorite of mine.

title: Well-paid FX trying hard to save the day
review:
"Constantine" is far faaar away from the the expectations everyone had and also from being a blockbuster.. If there's anything to it it's the special effects and they should NOT count more than 30% of a movie's quality. They say that film is the 7th art, so movies should express the creator's ideas/concepts through story and characters - to make others ask themselves questions, explore a different view of the world - or just make people laugh (like in comedies) or get their adrenaline going (thriler, action, horror etc).

There is nothing truly original about this movie..

So what was "Constantine"'s purpose?

Demolishing the biblical myth of Good and Evil as super-human forces, unjudgeable from our human a.k.a. limited point of view by saying it's just a game between God and Lucifer? And that they must be doing this for fun, playing us like marionettes? Geez, this is as old as the Greeks(which, you know, thought of gods as being pretty "human" in feelings and judgement). The film-maker could of at least add something to this ancient, saturated view of good&evil; try to give new arguments sustaining the theory, explore it with more depth or at least make the skepticism in the movie more ironic and fun, make it all much more pragmatic... But like this it seems like stealing a wannabe interesting-pragmatic-view just to have a pretext for making a movie... It's a horrible cliché and just for this I would have been ashamed to make so much publicity for this production :)

OK... so we definitely don't have here a revolutionary view of the universe.

Then, was this meant to be a get-my-adrenaline-going movie? Get freaked out by scary demons and be fascinated with the mysterious psychological games Gabriel, The Devil and Constantine play? hmmm... on a scale from 1 to 10 I would grade this goal with a 4... The only thing I didn't see coming was Gabriel helping Mammon and, although it's not at all new as well (see another angel, Lucifer, with his rebellion against God), it did turn out to be surprising (gotta hand it to the actress who played Gabriel, pretty convincing role). Stormare (Devil) was also good in his part, managing to get the best out of his poorly written lines.

Constantine's lines are really pathetic.. I mean, "This is John, John Constantine. ..asshole" It's only meant to be cool for fifth grade, right? Sounds like "Bond, James Bond". Come on ppl...couldn't they find a less-popular cliché to copy? pathetic, pathetic, pathetic. And also giving the demons "the finger"... For a swift, smooth, cool exorcist superhero in denial of his status kind of guy it's.. indefinably stupid, it makes the character look like a big fat Looser(this among many other things).

OK.. so storyline and suspense 0 points out of 10.

Acting - 4 for Constantine, 7 for Gabriel and the Devil, 5 for Angela.

The special FX were pretty good, but not exceptional, except for the Hell. I'm sure everyone can comment on this part, cause it's really simple to say whether you were impressed with visual effects or not.. cause they have a big impact on you in a movie.

All in all I see this as a very commercial movie, but one resembling a low-budget one.. Too many loose ends, too many clichés, too little concern for the substance. That's what happens when you only care about profit.

title: awful film... excellent trailer!!!
review:
Don't you just hate it when you see a trailer, make an note of the film and then when you finally get to see it its........ AWFUL?!!! Well this is one of those films.

I was expecting a matrix/end of days/devils advocate love child and what i got was a wannabe and never gonna be!!

Its a good performance by Keanu but the storyline is dire, something you would expect to see from a really low budget film

Wait till this comes to DVD and then at least you've got a nice Frisbee for the kids!!

Dave

title: the coolness of Keanu and the messages underneath
review:
This movie was awesome! I saw it in digital version in the cinema and I was astonished! Though the subject of the movie isn't realistic, I thought it was wonderful, containing lots of messages underneath. Also I thought the acting of Keanu Reeves and Rachel Weisz was great and the tension between them is almost touching my skin. Combined with a lot of exciting action and dry humor, it makes one movie you have to see.

The comment that Keanu can only play Neo, I think is the comment of a rather critical person, who doesn't have a clue where the story is all about. Yes, there's the coolness that is just part of being Keanu, but Neo is the goodness himself, when John Constantine is almost the opposite.

Don't go to movies with great expectations, it will always turn out bad...

title: hot and action packed
review:
First, keep in mind, this review is coming from someone who never read the Hellblazer comic book series.

Keanu Reeves plays John Constantine, a chain smoking exorcist who's trying to buy his way into heaven with his work. Not only can he exorcise demons, he can also travel to Hell and back. He meets a woman named Angela Dodson(Weisz) who's convinced her twin sister's death wasn't a suicide. She turns to Constantine for help.

This movie is a fun ride right from the start. It has great special effects, fun action sequences, and some sweet weapons for destroying demons. Unlike most others, I was pleased with Reeves's performance in this film. He plays the bad-ass characters well. Weisz is also excellent in her role. The only downside is some of the plot holes. We learn in the film of half-breeds that live on earth (some people are half-demon or half-angel). We also learn that hell has its own version of the bible. The things like this I wish the film would have given us more information on. For people who know their bible well, this movie will be especially frustrating.

Overall, I found this movie very enjoyable. I hope there will be a director's cut when the movie comes out on DVD. 8/10

Recommend if: *you like action *you like movies that involve spiritual warfare

Avoid if: *you don't like to see graphic violence with blood *you're offended by strong language

title: I Liked This Movie
review:
Reading the negative reviews here on IMDb, I wanted to say I liked the movie. Yes, it wasn't perfect. I thought there were too many characters and unexplained actions happening in the first 15 minutes, but that is what made the movie a mystery, and I like mysteries. Much of the fun was trying to figure out who everyone was and why they were doing the odd things they did. Reviewers who said they couldn't understand the plot, either you didn't try to understand it, or you REALLY didn't watch this movie at all, or you just aren't very smart.

Another thing I didn't care for, as another reviewer pointed out, was for a gay, weirdo, Italian Godfather-type Satan. As the lord of Hell, he didn't seem that scary, but he acted like a creepy old gay man who was trying to kiss Keanu, while running his hands up his legs, and leering at his crotch. Yes, a lot of gay men want to do this to Keanu, but I didn't like it. If I'm going to pay money to see a gay man make-out with Keanu, I would like it be romantic, not creepy.

For the reviewers who raved about the great job Stomare did as Satan, I felt the actress who played Satan in "The Passion" did a FAR BETTER job portraying the beautiful scariness of Lucifer. Lucifer means light, he shone with beauty but was full of evil wickedness. When Jesus is resurrected, we see his TRUE evil self as he howls and screams. Actually, the Balthazzar character, handsome and sexy on the outside, but completely evil inside, was a much better portrayal of Satan in this film than what they ended up with.

For all the reviewers who hate Keanu just because he is alive, I say, "Nobody wants to sit here wasting their time reading about how much HATE you have in your heart for him". It's too bad that most of you will be going to Hell, since your souls are consumed with such hatred for Keanu, there is NO way that you will be going to heaven. If you can't stand watching him, then why are you paying money to go see his films? The answer is, most of you are not telling the truth when you say you saw this movie. You wouldn't have paid money to see your anti-Christ, Mr. Reeves. If you had seen this film, you would have enjoyed it better.

The reviewers who said Rachel was the best thing in the movie, well, she was good. But she wasn't the best. The SFX was the best part of the film. The special effects were some of the best ever. (Although the bug demon was kinda weird.) The scenes of hell were great, the demons scary. I wish those scenes had gone on longer, but they were expensive, so they didn't. Heaven was beautiful, but we only saw it for couple of seconds at the end. The bullet-time glass at the end was great.

For the reviewers who said the film had humorous lines, intentional and unintentional, I agree with you. There was subtle humor, and some in-your-face humor. I laughed when Keanu hits Balthazzar with his specially made brass knuckles. I thought it was clever when they mass-produced Holy Water in the hospital's water system, a very unique way to SPRAY Holy Water on a crowd of demons.

For the comic purists who say the film is horrible because it doesn't match the comics in every detail: One, after 200 issues of comics, the movie would have been 3 years long. Two, make your own version, see if you could do any better. Yes, it would be nice if they were as faithful as LOTR, but that was a 10 hour trilogy, this wasn't. AND LOTR was not 100% faithful either. This movie was good in it's own way, and I liked it better being set in the hellish Los Angeles of smog-covered California, than the gay London of Europe. There is no way that Jude Law or another Brit could have done as good a performance in this film as Keanu did. PERIOD.

Yes, I own some of the early Hellblazer comics, up to #56. Stopped buying them when Prince Charles was possessed by a demon who ate his victims. They made Prince Charles a cannibal Jack The Ripper. Back in the early 1990's I found that offensive. Now that we have learned more about what the real Prince Charles is like, I don't think the comic was so off-the-mark as I did 13 years ago. When I was buying Hellblazer, they weren't Vertigo titles. I guess Vertigo came later. I was also buying early Sandman comics at that time also.

My conclusion: The film is for adults (no children under 15) with great special effects, an interesting mystery type story in a dark film-noir setting. Keanu is good, and sexy (he should have filmed the movie shirtless), the supporting actors were good. Stay after the credits to see a surprise ending, which leads to a sequel (like the Pirates OTC ending does).

Movie's Philosophy: There is a Hell, and Heaven, and God and Satan, demons and angels, whether you want to believe or not. There is a war going on for the souls of humans. If you wish to be redeemed and go to heaven, believing in God is not enough, you must be repentant, TRULY repenting your sinful life. You must be willing, like Jesus, to SACRIFICE yourself for others if necessary. Good eventually wins out over evil, though it may take a while. Sometimes good people die, but they go to Heaven, not Hell, as their ETERNAL reward. After we see Hell, we understand why humans would want to go to Heaven instead.

See this film for yourself, don't listen to Keanu-hating reviewers who probably didn't see the film anyway.

title: Problem, taking the Bible, hacking it up for entertainment and fable
review: I have read other reviews, one in particular basically says that the movie wasn't meant to be gospel(the truth) but rather entertainment, I get that. However, the FACT that Heaven is real, God is real and Satan is real, regardless of whether or not YOU believe, makes it a serious matter to propagate the fables of the Catholic church and to trifle with the truth written in the word of God. There is a Satan, he is a fallen angel. Men do NOT become angels when they die. No amount of good deed will EVER win you a trip to heaven, in fact, if you count on your deeds to earn your way to heaven, you will be disappointed and find yourself in the place referred to as hell. That's right. Only Jesus can offer eternal salvation to those who accept Him and His death on the cross to pay for all sin. No amount of good deeds will make you MORE saved or less saved. But with ONLY good deeds, you WILL be lost forever UNLESS you repent. That is the ONLY message of the Bible. It isn't about punishing yourself for past sin, trust me, if you sinned, you punished yourself. There is always consequences for sin, some worse than others. Murderers are often judged and receive the death penalty, but even a murderer CAN and WILL be saved if he/she TRULY believes in Christs immaculate birth, righteous life and His own sacrificial death on the Cross. And add to that, His resurrection on the 3rd day. Yes, it is real, it is serious and making a movie DELIBERATELY PERVERTING the scripture is WRONG. Sorry, but the truth isn't always the way you wish it to be. Now you have heard the truth of the Gospel, now it is in YOUR hands to decide. No one can make a decision for you except you. We all must appear before God at the judgment. But if you receive Jesus as your personal savior(not a priest who is every bit the sinner as you and I happen to be), but go to the HIGHEST priest, Jesus, He and He alone forgives sin. Do NOT accept fables, believe the truth.

title: get over Keanu as Constantine and you've got an enjoyable flick
review:
Completely disregard the comics, in every way. The comics are called Hellblazer, different name, different stuff. Watch this movie with a clean slate and you've got a pretty sweet movie that gets surprisingly harsh in what it is willing to show us - this flick doesn't pull any punches.

There is no shortage of reviews for this film on the internet, so that's as far as I'll go, but I will say this: The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen was a terrible movie. It was unfaithful to its comics. It was bad even if you never read the comics. Constantine is a pretty sweet movie. It's unfaithful to its source material. I'm sure having read the comics you will find a lot of things to complain about here, but just let go and enjoy it. The comics will always be there for you when you get home from the theater, and if they managed to make an enjoyable film despite not remaining true to the source material, that's still quite a feat.

See it. Enjoy it.

title: It's much better than you may have heard
review: Keeneu shows more humanity in this than the three Matrix movies put together. The story is good, follows the comic well. I liked the dual role that Rachel played and thought her work was some of the best she's done. Tilda Swenton is very good as the Arch Angel Gabriel. I would definitely suggest you not shy away from seeing the movie or buying it when it comes out on DVD. The movie left me wanting to know more about the characters and how the story proceeds. Guess that's why I've heard talk of doing a sequel. The movie was shot a little dark for me, it was hard to see the characters some of the time, but I"m finding that in a number of movies lately. I don't know if it's a homage to Film Noir or what but I don't like it.

title: Fan of the comic, Fan of the movie
review:
I don't know where the people with such strong foul opinions are coming from ... oozing out of the woodwork... spouting off claims that comic book fans hated this movie...

Do not speak for me.

I am the proud owner of Hellblazer comics starting from #1 back when it was first released and I enjoyed this film immensely.

I liked the plot, I liked the special effects, I liked the acting, direction, etc...

I LIKE THE COMIC

I LIKE THE MOVIE

title: Settles For Far Less Than What It Was Capable Of
review:
A fascinating fable of angels & demons with humans caught up in between, Frances Lawrence's directorial debut packs an interesting premise yet is unable to flap its wings due to issues of its own makings. Keanu Reeves' presence is no less than a divine intervention here coz without him, Constantine is very much a hopeless ride.

The story concerns a demonologist who has a reputation for dealing with the mystical and has been repenting for his past sins by sending demons back to hell, hoping his good deeds will finally grant him a place in heaven. But when he's approached by a police detective to investigate her twin sister's suicide case, he learns of a conspiracy that threatens all mankind.

Directed by Frances Lawrence, the first act is rather impressive & piques our interest with ease while paving the necessary groundwork. But it's unable to keep a firm grip on our attention for long as the plot only gets sillier & goofier with time and goes full bonkers in the finale. It is lacking in atmosphere, has no build-up whatsoever, and is missing the required seriousness.

It would've helped if the film had a dark, gothic vibe with skilfully executed moments of tension & suspense. What we get instead is a watered down version of a material with far greater potential. Keanu Reeves' charisma conjures more magic here than his performance but he does enough to keep us around till the end. Tilda Swinton is reliable as always while Rachel Weisz ably plays her role(s).

On an overall scale, Constantine has the beginnings of a cool, stylish & thrilling horror-fantasy but the story fails to capitalise on it. Somewhere along the line, the debutant filmmaker loses his grasp on the narrative, resulting in a finished product that settles for far less than what it was capable of. The cult following it has developed over the years may give the impression of it being an underrated gem. For me however, it was nothing but dull, bland & underwhelming.

title: It was an okay film I guess
review: There were some good things about Constantine. The special effects and cinematography are outstanding and keeps you interested. The music score is excellent, and there are some good performances. I do not care for Keanu Reeves, but he does an okay job in the title role, though his character could've done with more development. Rachel Weisz is a lovely actress and she is good here in two roles. Peter Stormare is fantastically suave and debonair in his villainous role. Tilda Swinton is the best though, she is absolutely delicious as the androgynous angel. Francis Laurence directs efficiently as well, and there are some good scenes such as the discovery of the relic in the desert- daft I admit though. However, the plot is very convoluted, and lacks a clear sense of direction, and the script feels rather sticky. In terms of character and storytelling, the film feels diluted. It certainly isn't a bad film, with the visuals, direction and decent performances, making up for the plot convolutions and the sticky moments in the screenplay. 6/10 Bethany Cox

title: Another Entertaining Movie from the One A.K.A Mr Reeves
review:
I watched this movie earlier this evening. While not overly impressed I still found this to be very entertaining and waaaay better than a lot of recent comic book style movies, such as Catwoman, Hellboy, League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, The Hulk, Elektra etc.

I am not familiar with the source material. I did however contrary to many reviews here, find Keanu Reeves to be very good in this film. His Character John Constantine is a chainsmoking, arrogant and obnoxious guy, who does not let people in to his personal life. He is dying of cancer and tormented by inner demons (as well as fighting real ones outside). Having been damned to hell, he is trying to somehow buy his way back to heaven by vanquishing demons on earth (which only he and a select few can see). I think he portrayed this individual very well, the supporting cast also gave decent performances. I seem to slightly disagree with many people here on Rachel Weisz's performance, while quite good was not exceptional as many have stated here.

The eventual meeting with the Devil was a little disappointing, but overall it was definitely not a bad movie. In fact I found it to be very entertaining and visually excellent.

I am not a big fan of Keanu Reeves as I have only really liked him in a few films. But here I think he performed well and the movie was all the better for it.

title: The second coming is a total failure
review:
Surprising new enactment of the sacrifice of a man who had always been in contact with the other side of reality in a vast fight against Lucifer to whom the world has been totally abandoned by God. And the sacrifice is supposed to save the world. Not by redeeming the sins of human beings. But by preventing the birth of Lucifer's son and the total take-over of the world by him. The strangest element is that everything is purely haphazard. There is no plan, no real perspective known and controlled by anyone, especially not God, and least of all Lucifer. It is pure opportunism on their sides and human beings are always taken in-between these two famously inconsequent and irresponsible characters and they have to accept, follow and suffer what the other two in their big conflict don't even know they produce. Even Archangel Gabriel is totally spaced out and corrugated and Lucifer will punish him by burning his wings and making him human and sensitive to suffering. Let's hope for eternity. The special effects are from time to time agreeable and pleasant but never really outstanding. The story is messy and obscure and the spear that had been used by a Roman soldier to pierce Jesus' side on the cross and had disappeared for some time reappears by pure luck somewhere in Mexico of all places. Naïve. And we don't know at all what's the use of it and what it brings to the story. The second coming of Lucifer's son is a failure. The second coming of some Jesus, new or old, is also a failure since Lucifer has to resuscitate him for him not to go to Hell for eternity. And they repeat as often as possible that He has a plan for anyone of us. In fact He and They have nothing for none of us. We are lost in a messy haphazard conflict between a truant God and a totally disorganized Lucifer. That's what divine providence amounts to: nothing at all.

Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, University Paris Dauphine, University Paris 1 Pantheon Sorbonne & University Versailles Saint Quentin en Yvelines

title: For those of you that want a CGI version of hell...
review: I Tivo'ed this and watched it with the idea it was really bad. It was not that bad. In fact it was pretty good. Yes the CGI is eye candy. Yes Keanu delivers his bad attitude lines in cheesy form. Yes the plot is silly. But if you look past those set backs you'll find some chemistry between Keanu and Rachel. I liked them together and the whole "I'm in it for myself...except now that I met you I do selfless things, ala Han Solo" thing has been done to death, but it works. I liked Keanu's character, bad boy, dammed to hell, trying to buy his way into heaven by banishing demons back to hell. That's new. I enjoy CGI when it's well done and relevant (liek here). 7/10 Not bad at all.

title: Best story in a long time ...
review:
In it's genre of movies, the story is most convincing, while not laking mind blowing visual effects, good acting blended with effects superbly, Also Keanu Reeves acting talent has been proved to be of the best.

I'm an orthodox, and I don't find this film in any way misleading. But sure this film is downright scary for the faint hearted. I also loved the role of Gabrielle, played by Tilda Swinton, she was also very keen at making us scared. Thanks also to excellent screenplay and the director, Francis Lawrence who obviously was the weaver of it all. I really don't find why not this movie gets 10/10.

Highly Recommended.

title: Watch this movie
review: This movie is amazing. I absolutely love Keanu Reeves is my favorite actor. I love all of his movies. He is the best. this movie kept me in till the very end. This movie is all about this guy trying to buy his way into heaven and as you can guess this movie is beastly. i would give all of his movies 10 out of 10, and this deserves it. i love it. if you like Keanu watch Bill and Teds excellent adventure. that movie is the funniest ever. i love it and the matrix is just. man that sums it up. Neo is incredible. i love it and i know everyone else does to it is the best. So go out and get this movie. you will not regret it. i can promise you of that.

title: Pointless!
review: There was only one thing in this movie that saved it from being an almighty disaster - the special effects. They really are quite impressive. The plot doesn't seem to have any direction though and it's all over the place....a lot of parts in the movie should have been consigned to the "deleted scenes" section. It started out as a very serious and dark supernatural horror flick then turned into some big yawn horror-comedy. Even more tragic is the fact that it's one long anti-tobacco advert! The acting was pretty good - can't blame the actors for how lackluster the movie turned out - that ought to be reserved entirely for the scriptwriter and the director/producer. Reeves and Weisz are brilliant together. The romantic undertone to the pairing didn't match the mood of the film at all. In all, i've seen worse but this was one that could have had cult appeal if it had been done right.

title: plot too unfocused
review:
About half way through the movie, I started to get confused. I still don't know what the Spear of Destiny had to do with anything besides at the end when Angela almost gets stabbed with it. What was with the Mexican who found it. It was like he became possessed after finding it and then going to LA. But, why was he possessed and by who. Was it Satan? I don't know. And I didn't get Gavin Rossdale's character. Who was he supposed to be. First, I thought he was the son of Satan, but he bites the dust half way through. What was he trying to do? And what was with Gabriella. I thought she was an angel since she had wings, but she is seen at the same place as Balthazar and is trying to kill Angela.

Then the part where Constatine holds Angela underwater in the tub made no sense. I get the near death experience part, but how did he know she would go to hell and not heaven. And why did he have to hold a cat when he sent himself to hell to look for Angela's sister. And how did Satan suddenly show up at the end? I could go on and on with more plot holes. But, I guess since this was based on a comic a ton of info got left out. And if you have never heard of the comic like me, the characters and what they do don't make a lot of sense.

FINAL VERDICT: I thought it was too confusing, so I don't recommend it.

title: Dangerous Habits...
review:
"Dangerous Habits" is the title of the Hellblazer graphic novel upon which "Constantine" is based. It is also a decent description of the pattern that Hollywood has recently been taking to adapting graphic novels. While I do accept that movies that are adapted from novels need a little trimming, Hollywood had the habit of re-writing the whole premise to make it "original". "Sin City" was really the one true exception, but in turn, it almost created a backlash for the director.

The cast is (for the most part) exceptional. Rachel Wiesz as the detective with an unknown power is charming as always. Tilda Swinton does her androgynous turn as the angel Gabriel, Djimon Hounsou as the African mystic Midnite is perfect, and Peter Stomare, a great character actor recently seen as the torturer in "The Brothers Grimm", puts a nice touch on the Satan character. Heck, even Gavin Rossdale from Bush is fun as the half-breed demon Balthazar.

But unfortunately, Keanu Reeves is cast as Constantine--mistake one. Anyone who has read Hellblazer knows that even in the dreariest of moments, Constantine has a little life in him. Reeves, on the other hand, decides to redo Neo as a psychic detective with wood in his heart. Not good. Mistake two--the script falls on its face. We never truly understand why Satan and his minions want to torture Constantine so bad. The explanation given was so weak that Satan would have a grudge on many more people than just Constantine. Also, Constantine from the novel was always selfish, and would always use magic to resolve his problems, which only created more problems for himself and those he loved. Not necessarily in this case. In this movie, he is a relatively moral character. The role of the other characters are pretty much warped from the original story. Finally, by trying to use elements of one novel with a mutation of another ("Dangerous Habits" and "Son of Man", respectively), the filmmakers cram too much in to even develop any characters.

On the whole, Constantine is a relatively fun flick, but a)check your logic in at the front desk, and b) Hellblazer fans should think twice before seeing it.

title: I was born with this curse...
review: ... and unfortunately it showed in this mediocre attempt at the "end of days" genre. The writing and direction in this film are all over the place, despite the incredible source material of Alan Moore's popular "Hellblazer" comic book series. Keanu Reeves is plastic and predictable as chain-smoking demon fighter John Constantine and the effects in this movie rely far too much on the same stop action and slow motion clichés that were exploited to death in "The Matrix". There are two performances which keep this movie from being a one-star mutt... Rachel Weisz is superb within the restraints of the dead script, elevating the material as much as possible, and Tilda Swinton shines as a creepily androgynous Archangel Gabriel. Other than that this film simply missed the mark.

title: Great film - Slammed by Industry Acolytes Unjustly
review:
I love the fact that the robotic industry weasels have flooded the boards with the same comments, over and over.

"What were they thinking? This movie is terrible. Rachel Weisz is an up and coming star - watch her star shine bright in the future!" First of all, Rachel Weisz does a good job - but she is quite frankly overrated and over-hyped. This movie, on the other hand, is quite good, and has subtext lacking in most recent feature films, but it's simple enough for everyone to enjoy. If you have even the most base form of a soul, this movie should touch you in some way.

I'm quite surprised at the lengths that the industry goes to to bury this picture so it's "type" isn't made again.

An entertaining, top-notch film.

title: Intelligentally created comic book action adventure!!
review:
There will always be the typical arguments about this film. Some will adore it, some will hate it and complain about it to no end. Fact remains that it pulled in hundreds of millions at the box office. Does that make it good?? No. It just makes it popular hence all the difference in opinions. I have never read the Hellblazers comic books so I went into this with no expectations and was pleasantly blown away by it.

Keanu Reeve's acting ability is limited, that's no secret but nonetheless there are some roles that have him stamped all over it such as Neo in the Matrix series, or any brooding, quiet type action hero and the lead role of John Constantine seems to fit him like a glove. Constantine appears to be your typical action horror film and not hard to create but the real genius behind Constantine that sets it apart from all the rest if that it actually becomes a very intelligent, complex thriller filled with religious overtones and an interesting plot line. I can't disagree more with some IMDb critics who called the plot "flat" and Constantine's character underdeveloped. I thought the writers of the film (also writers of the comic) did an amazing job of creating these characters in one film. They perhaps gave us too much if they're hoping to turn this into a franchise. Reeves' Constantine is a dark lonely sort who has struggled with his ability to see demons since he was a child. His inner turmoil and emotionally repressed state comes through in a major way. He has very few close friends, family so to speak and one by one in this film they are killed off. They were great characters and I was sad to see each one go because they had so much more potential but it was necessary for us to see the life which Constantine lives. Rachel Weisz as the lead actress and somewhat romantic interest does a great job. Weisz is very versatile and interesting actress and is easy to watch. She seems to take any role with ease. Reeves and her have great chemistry and they work well together on screen.

Francis Lawrence who, up until now, has been known only for music videos does an amazing job as his directorial debut. The special effects were NOT cheesy as some critics will say but rather subtly used which is much nicer change. The film was not flagrantly full of CGI and annoying fake effects. The action was non stop and on top of that comes an incredible story. The religious aspects however fictional they may be are interesting and we are given more and more information as we go along and you can't help but be caught up in this spiritual battle on earth between Constantine and the half breeds (half demon, half human.) On top of that there are several scenes where we get a glimpse into hell which is kept so brief that it keeps us wondering and imagining the horrors. The appearance near the end of Satan at first seems very tacked on and he's not very impressive.
