A catholic trying to redeem himself, after a failed attempted suicide? Jumping back and forth with a holy gun?

Aiming to go to Heaven, after death?

He is the very antithesis of his namesake. Not to mention, an example of blatant disregard to the basis of catholicism.

Played by a particularly stiff Keanu Reeve, to booth...

I couldn't help, but seeing the ironic, sarcastic, dastardly brilliant comic character planning how to use the idiotic movie character as a stand in, for the next time he has to scam Satan.

Calling the writers of this mess half-baked, is being gentle.

Beyond having ignored the very nature of the work that supposedly inspired theirs, they didn't even manage to write a coherent plot. Which is creative writing 101...

In all,this movie is a waste of the viewers'time.

title: Nice supernatural horror thriller. Doesn't matter if you haven't read the comics!
review:
This is a nice supernatural horror thriller on its own.

You don't have to know the comic Hellblazer on which is based.

Keanu Reeves, Rachel Weisz and Tilda Swinton are looking good for the main roles. Shia LaBeouf, as the after-teenage age sidekick is good too (these roles are more suitable for him and certainly not of a leading man).

There are some plot holes and inconsistencies, but the flow of the movie is suspenseful enough to keep you interested. The visuals are OK and you can expect a couple of disgusting scenes.

Overall: It's an entertaining movie nevertheless. Stay for an after credits secret scene too!

title: Keanu & Rachel's Excellent Adventure
review: First things first, this bears little to no resemblance to the comics but let's put that aside and judge it on its own merits. All things considered, it's not a bad movie of its type. It's entertaining enough, despite feeling like a mash-up of familiar exorcist and superhero action movie tropes. Some of the CGI isn't up to snuff and there aren't really any memorable scenes. Keanu Reeves and Rachel Weisz are fine, though this is more up his alley than hers. She's better than this type of movie. Shia LaBeouf is amusing in a part that's not really needed. Tilda Swinton steals every scene she's in. Djimon Hounsou is also good. Fans of the Hellblazer comics are most likely to be disappointed, and that's understandable, but the movie really is not bad for what it is.

title: I loved the action
review:
This is one of my favorite action horror films, after getting use to seeing Keanu Reeves as Neo in The Matrix I never expected to see him pull off another character that I would love. The thing i seem to like about this movie is how Keanu Reeves manages to keep his demeanour on the sad, weird don't care attitude all throughout the movie, the world coming to an end didn't even seem to move him, his selfish ambition to make heaven by all cause pushed him off the edge of sane behaviour to a point where you start to wonder if this guy is real.

The film is based on a comic book character and the screenplay was done by Kevin Brodbin and Frank Capello, taking stories from the Hellblazer comic book, and the main plot elements were taken from the "Dangerous Habits" story arc and the "Original Sins" trade paperback.

John Constantine is a character created by popular comic book writer/creator Alan Moore; the character was given his own comic book title, Hellblazer in 1988 and it was published by DC Comics under its Vertigo Comics imprint.

John Constantine is a man with the ability to perceive and communicate with half-angels and half-demons in their true form. After an attempted suicide gone wrong John's soul is eternal damned to go to hell. Constantine then goes on an exorcism rampage sending demons back to Hell so as to win enough favour to get to heaven.

His quest led him to meet a troubled police detective, whose sister just committed suicide; while they work together to unravel the truth behind it, the stumble upon a plot for world destruction.

Similarities and differences can be found in the portrayal of the character, from his appearance to the reason of his damnation. John Constantine is British in the comic book, other than the American as he is portrayed in the film. His reason for damnation was also changed in the film, his ability to see half breeds for who they really are (which is not an ability he posses in the comic book) was the reason he tried to kill himself leading to his damnation. In the comic book the reason for his damnation was his involvement in the summoning of a demon that killed a young girl.

Received with mixed reviews, Constantine is not one that many will like, but there is something about the after taste this movie gives you, the idea that an ongoing action packed battle is going on here on earth for the winning of souls, was fun to think of.

The movie does have some inconsistency that looks too large that the makers actually missed it, they made God look a little weak, like things were going on and he just let it, also the devil being taken unawares by a coup, all this made it look like God and the Devil don't have a hold on their minions.

www.lagsreviews.com

title: Hellacool
review:
Constantine is a movie about the exploits of a surly chain smoking exorcist who goes by the name of John Constantine. Towards the start of the film he receives some bad news regarding his future prospects, and this bad news coupled with the revelation that once he dies he is unavoidably hell bound go some way to explaining perhaps why indeed he is so irrefutably surly. And who could blame him? Now I know that Keanu Reeves has got his fair share of critics, his range of emotional depth isn't wondrous to behold and he's never really going to bring you to tears, however I think all this makes him perfect for the role. His character never really betrays any depth or emotion, because he's not supposed to. He's supposed to be cool, and like it or not, Keanu Reeves can be cool.

His knowledge of the occult is explained to the viewer through his association with the inexperienced characters of the film, namely Shia Labeouf and more frequently Rachel Weisz. Weisz gives a decent performance, she provides the female lead of the movie but never really manages to grab your attention or steal any of the scenes she is in. The usually very watchable Shia on the other hand is almost completely superfluous and his irksome performance is as easily forgettable as his turn in I, Robot was (yes he was in I, robot). Now I've never read the Hellblazer comics/graphic novels that the movie is based on and so I don't know whether "Kramer, Chaz Kramer" is a noteworthy enough character as the Robin to Constantines Batman to demand his inclusion into the movie, no matter how weak his portrayal. I imagine he must be. Either way, he's not really worth mentioning.

Other notable characters include Tilda Swantons genderly challenged Gabriel who is the liaison between Constantine and God (of all people), Djimon Honsous clearly biased Voodoo shaman Papa Midnight and a horrendously cringey Balthazaar, all of whom share various levels of animosity with Constantine. The most enjoyably performance though comes from Lucifer himself, portrayed by an excellent Peter Stormore in a very memorable scene. I can't discuss that too much though as his appearance takes place in the latter stages of the film, dangerously close to spoiler territory.

The lack of any conventional love interest between the leading male and leading lady is refreshing and the bleak post apocalyptic depiction of hell with the semi-headless demons scuttling along through the wreckage of dilapidated cars and decrepit buildings is genuinely creepy. In fact the film is visually very pleasing, maintaining it's dark and stylish mood throughout.

This film is not going to confuse you or make you think too hard, it's not going to move you or change the way you look at the world. It's just something to sit back, watch and enjoy. It's plot is fairly linear, but it works. There's little in the way of character development or chemistry, but that works too. I'm aware that it's not going to be for everyone, and given its (in my opinion) strangely low current score I'm sure there will be other reviews the polar opposite of mine who claim Keanu was a poor casting choice and that the lovable scamp Shia is the only saving grace of an otherwise empty and soulless film, and I understand why some people won't have liked it. I know there are other people who didn't like this movie because they found it to be nothing at all like their beloved Hellblazer comics (and from what I've read, they're probably right), but there's always going to be people who dismiss something that doesn't hold true to the original rather than judging it on its own merit. At the end of the day though, I think your opinion of this film boils down to one thing, whether you think it's cool or not. And I liked it. I thought it was cool.

title: Mostly incomprehensible, but otherwise pretty
review:
Keanu Reeves clashes with Satan...again.

Adapted from the comic-book Hellblazer (but renamed to avoid confusion with Hellboy and Hellraiser), John Constantine first appeared in an issue of Swamp Thing and soon got his own series. The character is from Liverpool but the movie version transplants him to LA (it's a more photogenic environment, let's be honest). He's supposed to be a psychic, occult detective but it's never explicitly mentioned what he is in the movie, which is the first instance of confusion the viewer will encounter.

Constantine ends up involved in a plot with LAPD detective Angela Dodson and her dead twin sister (both played by the lovely Rachel Weisz) which leads to confrontations with various angels and demons. So much happens in this film, but hardly any of it is explained. Don't get me wrong, I hate endless exposition, but Francis Lawrence tries to deliver virtually ALL of it with visual storytelling and it just doesn't work. There are so many random, unintelligible and moments that will alienate many viewers render the bulk of the film completely incomprehensible.

Francis Lawrence fills the movie with lots of symmetrical photography and beautifully eloquent shots that act as a muted counterpoint to the fake CGI, and the sound design is thankfully down-played. In the hands of a less-talented director (Brett Ratner, Len Wiseman) this film would have been loud and unsightly with lots of stutter-cuts and 'impossible camera' shots. I'm glad that Lawrence does not use this approach for his feature films.

It all looks very pretty, but it'll last in your memory about 5 seconds after the credits roll (there's a scene after the credits too).

title: So What?
review: For a movie produced in 2005, some crucially amazing editing choices were made which allowed for spectacular special effects. I was particularly blown away by the provocative depiction of hell and his anticipated offspring, Mammon. However, this film took too many creative liberties when illustrating Roman Catholic theonomy, it's almost as if God and Satan were card playing buddies and Jesus was nowhere to be found. Some of the religious context is so poorly represented that I had to chuckle a bit. We see multiple references to 'reverse baptisms', and demons pushing against the wombs of women. Jesus can be seen every two seconds on some form of cross, but his name wasn't mentioned favorably once. The stories plot ultimately says that God and Satan are running some sort of puppet show, negating Christian theology of Christ's death and resurrection. Additionally, Reeves objective was at sometimes unclear, especially when he attempts to portray and angst ridden hell-bound medium... he appears slightly goofy. After I saw the movie, I had to wonder, "What was the moral of the story? Did I just spend an hour and a half watching a series of incohesive events that lead to a conclusion that I already knew (suicide is bad)?" In end, I just chalked it up to a mediocre action film.

title: Cheesy Popcorn Entertainment
review:
Constantine is an action horror film directed by Francis Lawrence as his directorial debut.It stars Keanu Reeves as John Constantine,together with with Rachel Weisz, Shia LaBeouf, Tilda Swinton, and Djimon Hounsou. The film is based on Vertigo Comics' Hellblazer comic book.

Constantine portrays the lead character,John Constantine as a cynic with the ability to perceive and communicate with half-angels and half-demons in their true form. He seeks salvation from eternal damnation in Hell for a suicide attempt in his youth. Constantine exorcises demons back to Hell in a bid to earn favor with Heaven but has become weary over time. With death looming, he helps a troubled police detective learn the truth about her sister's death while simultaneously unraveling a much larger and darker plot.

Constantine solid production values and an intriguing premise but it lacks focus to be interesting,absorbing and engaging.It has a messy script that even talented cast involved like Keanu Reeves and Rachel Weisz can't save this movie from boredom.

Overall,Constantine turns out to be a cheesy popcorn entertainment despite having supernaturals and spirituals involved in the story.

title: Why not give the character a different name?
review:
I've been a fan of the HELLBLAZER comics for years. When I first heard of a film adaptation, I was really excited. This excitement was quickly diminished once I discovered that the character was not only going to be Americanized but that he was going to be played by, of all the possible actors, Keanu Reeves.

Had they gotten a competent and talented actor to portray an Americanized version of Constantine, this would have been a much easier pill to swallow. John Cusack, Johnny Depp, Edward Norton and Leonardo DiCaprio all immediately come to mind as good choices who could portray Constantine accurately (albeit without a British accent).

When the trailer for CONSTANTINE was first released, I thought there was a chance it could be good. And then I saw it in the theaters and was completely annoyed. Here are a number of things that I found to be glaring problems with this movie when held in comparison to the source material:

-John is not a magician in this film, he's a simple exorcist who has an ability to see half-demons. This is fundamental to the character and it's been completely ignored in this adaptation.

-In the comics, John is Hell-bound because of some bad decisions he made in his youth while experimenting with magic, decisions which resulted in the death of a little girl and of some of his friends. John was not an irredeemable character, but it made sense. In this film, that incredible aspect of his character is ignored and the reason John is going to Hell? Because he committed suicide as a way to stop plagues of visions. Wow, what a horrible guy. Can anyone blame him for being such a jerk?

-In the "Dangerous Habits" story, John contracts cancer, just like in the film. In the film, he's cured because Lucifer removes the cancer to give him a chance to fall because he's redeemed himself and is rising up to Heaven. This also ruins a key aspect of the character, which is on perfect display in the comic. In the comic, John sells his soul to three separate, high-ranking demons. Then he commits suicide and when all three come at once to claim him, John gives them a choice -- they can either tear apart Hell in a brutal war to claim his soul or they can cure him until they can work this out for themselves. It's a wonderful scene which showcases John's conman nature -- and a scene which is capped off beautifully when after being cured, John lights up a fresh cigarette and flips the bird to the demons. This is ruined in the film when at the end, John reaches for a pack of gum.

-And what I feel is the greatest injustice is this film embraces the extremely antiquated notion of suicide = eternity of torture in Hell. This horrible belief has caused innumerable families and friends who have lost people to suicide unimaginable emotional pain, because the Catholic church wants them to believe that their loved ones are suffering in Hell. The comic book never took sides in any sort of religious debate -- it borrowed elements from a number of different sources and crafted its own unique mythology. The filmmakers chose to be lazy and go with an easy way out.

All that being said, there are good things in this movie. And over time, I've given it some additional chances. And I've found that over time, the Catholic stuff aside, my biggest problem with this film is that it changed so much from the source material. With all these changes that were made, the film only needed to make one further change -- call the main character something other than John Constantine. Had they done that, I doubt anyone could claim in a court of law that this film bore anything more than a passing resemblance to HELLBLAZER. And had they made that one, little change, my review of this film would probably be an 8 as opposed to a 4.

**EDIT**

Since I wrote this review, I've seen Constantine a few more times. While the problems of the film are still very much there (particularly the suicide aspect, which in my mind is absolutely unforgivable), my views on the movie have softened. Given how little resemblance the film bears to the source material, I'd advise any fans of the comic to view this movie as a completely different animal, and think of these two characters sharing the same name as being a bizarre coincidence.

title: Very nice imagery
review:
The movie particularly impressed me in how it depicted its subject visually. People say the special effects are great, but that's the implementation. It's the vision behind the effects that makes the movie look good. It's also clear that there's a background to this movie, that it builds on something, and this adds to its impact. I haven't read the comics, but I assume this background comes from there.

The downside for me was the character Angela. I think it's partly Rachel Weisz not fitting the role of a police detective with some killings behind her, and partly because the premise of the character just didn't work. Keanu Reeves' usual wooden acting fitted his role rather well, on the other hand.

All in all, the movie was never boring, wasn't too annoying, and had some visually impressive moments. I'd give it 7.5, but will round it to 8.

title: Dangerous Habits
review:
Chain-smoking "Hellblazer" John Constantine goes from DC Comics' "Vertigo" (aimed at "adult" readers) to the movies for actor Keanu Reeves. They called it/him "Constantine" and hoped Mr. Reeves would help the film survive the ill-advised title change. The resulting story is nicely directed, imaginatively edited, and stylishly photographed - by Francis Lawrence, Wayne Wahrman, and Philippe Rousselot - but, the dynamic trio aren't able deliver the original, much more intriguing Liverpudlian. The plot starts out fine, but becomes somewhat overloaded and confusing during the running time.

The film was based (very loosely!) on Garth Ennis' first "Hellblazer" story - entitled "Dangerous Habits" and running through issues #41-46 (May-October, 1991) of the comic. It should be available as a separate "graphic novel" in your local disappearing comic shop - or online, if the store is already gone. The story dealt with Constantine's deadly lung cancer diagnosis. With some changes, best pal Chas Chandler/Kramer (Shia LaBeouf) is included, but you have to wait until after the credits for his full story. Rachel Weisz is almost a female co-star, playing twins (Constantine's twin is not mentioned).

****** Constantine (2/8/05) Francis Lawrence ~ Keanu Reeves, Rachel Weisz, Shia LaBeouf, Tilda Swinton

title: Keanu Reeves as a sort of super exorcist, still it's a fun to watch movie.
review:
My first though when I started to see this movie was; this is some kind of exorcist film. Not quite wrong, but I would call it a super exorcist. A dilemma similar to the whole movie from 1974 called "the exorcist" was here solved in about 10 minutes and then Keanu Reeves goes of to kill demons, monsters, visit hell and fight angels. Obviously this movie has a lot of Catholic, religious and occult stories mixed together. But it is a fun fantasy movie with an obvious horror film feel to it.

Keanu Reeves as John Constantine, has by many critics been called his worst performance, I fail to see why. It's not his best, but I felt he created a very cool and enigmatic character. Rachel Weisz as Angela Dodson was just plain good. Shia LaBeouf as Chas Kramer was a good character, which sadly was forgotten in about half the movie and never got the chance to evolve. They should have involved him more into the film or just ditched the whole character. Tilda Swinton as Gabriel and Peter Stormare as Satan is just great.

The effects like most movies today, are great. What can I say, it's a lot of high budget CGI that creates some really cool demons and monsters.

I give this movie a 6/10. Half original idea, good acting, but moved a little slow. Still fun to watch if you like religious based horror films.

title: heck of a movie
review:
I've heard all of the negative opinions on this movie, and I simply don't agree. This film was engaging from the moment it began all the way through the end.

Keanu does a fine job in the title role. Rachel Weisz is all kinds of fun to watch. They make me believe in this world and except it without question.

It's what I love about cinema, taking me to another world and making me love the characters within it. The story is fun and introduces us to plenty of interesting characters and situations.

Great movie

title: Enjoyable if hard to follow
review:
Constantine (2005, Dir. Francis Lawrence)

John Constantine (Reeves), the supernatural exorcist, who has been to hell and back and spends his days battling demons, has been requested by a police detective Angela Dodson (Weisz) whose twin sister had mysteriously died. Alongside his companion, the young and eager Chas Kramer (LaBeouf), Constantine searches for the truth behind this death, before his own catches up with him.

There are some excellent effects shown, as well as some interesting, but well used casting choices, but Constantine has so much more added into the plot, that it is not that hard to get lost a long the way. Even with this problem, it is still possible to enjoy some wonderful sequences.

You ever think if you told me now that maybe I could help out?  Chas Kramer (Shia LaBeouf)

title: Djimon.
review: Well first of all his name is Djimon Hounsu, some of you people can't even spell his name. I know because it has a distinctive similarity to the word digimon. Also, i looked on the back of the DVD. Not that i like digimon. Because i certainly don't. Also, i actually played the game Constantine on Ps2 before i saw the movie, so unfortunately i already knew some of the plot. Plus my brother lent it to someone for like a year (literally) so i couldn't watch it. Anyway, about the movie: I though it had a good and interesting storyline, plus it had demons in it, and i'm obsessed with demons. Some of the scenes were done well although i must say they were dragged down a bit by the weight of Keanu Reeves' incoherent mumbling. I must say that yes, some of it was hard to follow ( the storyline i mean, not with your eyes). Also, the first scene, almost every word and every camera shot, angle, whatever you want to call it, was the same as in the game, except for the bit where the guy turns into a gray old man, which i found to be quite humorous. Does anyone agree? Or have i just got a sick sense of humour? All in all, an interesting yet strange movie with a very creative storyline. 7/10.

title: Strange but entertaining
review:
Constantine is a good supernatural/ horror film directed by Frances Lawrence (I am Legend.) The elements of good horror mixed with an action extravaganza both keep the audience entertained and thrilled. At the same time, the story also is fast and on par between any horror film since The Sixth Sense. Constantine not only is good in these areas but also in the special effects and cinematography departments which make the film feel dark and disturbing. Speaking of dark and disturbing being two of the main moods of the story, the other moods also give context and originality to its layers.

The only thing i can uphold about is, in some scenes its a bit far-fetched but, not that you haven't realised.

title: Constantine
review:
In 2005 Francis Lawerence, who most recently made I am Legend, directed an adaptation of the Hellblazer comic series simply titled Constantine. At the time there was an outcry from the fans because their comic hero's features were originally based on Sting, but Keanu Reeves was cast in the part. From then on they were already fighting a losing battle with the fans. So how does it compare otherwise?

The film's story is based around a conspiracy to invoke an ancient prophecy and release the Anti-Christ and the end of days. There are many key players in the conspiracy and not all are who they seem, subverting our ideals on Good vs Evil.

Rachel Weisz plays detective Angela Dodson, who after having a premonition of her sisters death, sets about trying to prove it wasn't suicide. Through her investigation she meets Constantine, who unveils the real world behind what we see. It soon becomes apparent that Angela has a far greater part to play in the prophecy.

Constantine and Angela must travel to the very depths of hell to stop the prophecy and fight demons of many forms and the occasional angel too.

Keanu Reeves does well to fill the Constantine character with the same level of sarcasm and wit of the comics. The film portrays him as someone who on the outside doesn't care about anyone but himself. He's killing demons to buy his way into heaven. But he is also fiercely loyal to his friends who have a nasty habit of dying. Also lifted straight from the comics.

The supporting cast are excellent too: Shia Lebouef in an early role as John's trusted yet unused sidekick. Max Baker as the Q type character who provides John with his arsenal of weapons including the Holy Knuckle Duster. Tilda Swinton impresses with her turn as the ambiguous Angel Gabriel, who may be playing both sides. But, even although he's only in it for fifteen minutes, It's Peter Stormare as Lucifer that blows the audience away. He really encapsulates the embodiment of evil perfectly, slithering and sliding around every shot hissing in Constantines ear. Dressed immaculately in white with black tattoos up and down his arms and neck. They couldn't have done it better.

The special effects in this film aren't widely remembered, but watching it again this morning I noticed that they have a lot in common with Nightwatch and Daywatch with exploding glass hanging in the air and people being pulled through walls backwards. It's well worth watching again.

For Movie Reviews, news and opinion like no other. Plus the kick ass Bi-weekly pod-cast go to www.fightrunner.co.uk

title: Holy shotgun, Constantine-man!
review:
I have never really gotten into the world of Constantine despite the fact, that it has stories in it written by some of my favourite comic book writers. The character hasn't never really interested me enough, though it does hover around matters which I personally find appealing. That's why I really didn't have any expectations of this film.

It has parts in it I liked and parts I didn't like. The character of Constantine is, as far I know, pretty faithful to the original with the exception of that originally he's a Brit, who looks like Sting. And he's not so much of an action man. The world comics are set in and the world that the movie has seem pretty similar to me. But as I said I am not an expert on this matter, so I am sure, that the people who actually have read more than a couple of Hellblazer comics will beg to differ.

So let's tackle it shall we? John Constantine (Keanu Reeves) is a modern day wizard, who battles against the daemons of hell to make amends in order to gain back his place in heaven. He finds out that certain parties are trying to get son of Satan on earth. He gets help from a police Angela Dodson (Rachel Weisz), who's dead twin sister seems to have something to do with the case. I am sure you'll fill in the blanks.

The plot is clichéd as heck. Nothing in the movie comes as a surprise and the "surprise plot twist" are so old, that even a blind could see them coming from far. That actually wouldn't be a problem, as I actually liked the visual appearance of the film, but the direction was very lacking: it seemed to lack enough tensity to keep me on the edge of my seat.

As I said, I liked the visual appearance of the film. There are some pretty nice SFX in there, but sadly the cons do win over the pros here. Constantine is not biggest piece of garbage in the comic book movie genre, far from it, but spectacular or memorable film it isn't. Which is a kind of a shame really.

title: silly but better than some
review:
John Constantine is a chain-smoking exorcist with only a few months left to live. Although he knows that he is already destined to spend eternity in hell for a mortal sin he committed in the past, John is still attempting to find redemption by dedicating himself to battling the demonic forces that exist just beneath the surface of our known reality and which have lately been making a greater effort to cross over from their world to ours.

I imagine that the Catholic Church must be rather pleased with this film, especially considering the black eye it suffered at the hands of Dan Brown's "The Da Vinci Code." Here the incantations and paraphernalia of the Roman church have a great deal of efficacy in keeping the demonic forces Constantine encounters subdued and at bay.

Strictly as a movie and not as a theological document, "Constantine" is a slightly better-than-average demonic thriller that goes back and forth between the world of humans and the shadowy netherworld inhabited by angels and demons and even a few creatures that fall somewhere in between. In a role not all that far removed from the one he played in the "Matrix" movies, Keanu Reeves once again functions as the flawed Everyman hero whose job it is to save humanity from a fate worse than, in this case, eternal death. We're more willing to accept the silliness of the premise knowing we have Reeves to guide us along the movie's path. The special effects are impressive for the most part, with special credit going to the art designers for their imaginative view of hell (which looks much like a city after it's been destroyed by a nuclear explosion). The film is, admittedly, too long and the nonsense quotient begins to run dangerously high long about the last half hour. But "Constantine" is, overall, sufficiently imaginative to keep us interested for most of its duration.

title: Creepy but great!
review:
I wasn't sure I was going to like this movie when I first saw the trailers. A friend of mine who adores Keanu talked me into seeing the movie.

I'm so glad I did. It was wonderful! The plot was a creepy but great battle between heaven and hell on earth.

The casting for the movie was perfect. It was a very interesting take on the comic book hero.

THERE IS A SECOND ENDING AFTER THE CREDITS!!!! Be sure to stay to watch it. I don't want to give away what it is but it's worth waiting for.

Interesting trivia: I found out that originally Constantine was supposed to have a different love interest than who is portrayed currently in the movie. It was supposed to be one of the half breeds he kills which would have made the scene even more emotional than it is now.

title: Constantine
review: I found this movie pretty good. I am a fan of Keanu Reeves and I think he acted real good in this movie. Very convincing. Rachel Weisz was good too and they really made the movie come alive. The story is nice, an exorcist on earth who is going to die pretty soon and tries to buy his place into heaven. He doesn't want to go to hell, and that is logical, 'cause he sends a lot of demons there. Constantine has a lot of black humor which I like a lot. It's also very ironical that after all the demons he has defeated, he's going to die of cancer. A nice touch at the end of the movie is, when you think he will lit another cigarette, that it is just some chewing gum. You can see that he will not make the same mistake twice. The special effects in this movie are good and there are some scary moments, which make the film interesting. I find it advisable for everyone to go and see this movie. You won't regret it.

title: Constantine goes to hell but comes back swinging
review: Constantine, a man with the ability to see angels and demons who walk among us, literally goes to hell and back looking for a detective's dead sister. He is enlisted to determine the strange events surrounding Angela's (the cop)dead twin sister, Isabell. While on his mission, John Constantine encounters demons of all sorts and discovers a plan for hell on earth which needs the help of a divine being. Constantine manages to thwart the bad guys(and good angel) and come back swinging! This movie flat out rocks! The story is great, the effects beautiful, and the actors fulfill their roles fantastically. GO SEE IT! You will find yourself realizing how real heaven and hell can be in today's world. For example, all Constantine must do to travel-to hell is find some water, a puddle or a pool, say a few words and BAM! He's in hell. It is later explained in the movie that water is the universal conduit for traveling to hell. Very cool, very good movie. A must see!

title: Negative review
review: We went to see this movie because we love Keanu Reeves but were very disappointed. Boring is the operative word for "Constantine". What happened here? How can a movie with Keanu and Rachel be so dull? We felt as if we'd seen it all before. Constantine moved from one special effects scene to another as if special effects make up for content. That only works for the kids - not for those of us who enjoy the story as much as the effects. The only bright spot in the movie was the guy who played Satan. That was nicely done. Also, I'm no arm-waving evangelical but found myself very put off by the perversion of Christian theology this movie promoted.

title: Ridiculous
review: I sat through an hour and 25 minutes of this film, and had absolutely no desire to watch it to the end. This is about the stupidest movie I've ever seen!

title: Keanu steals the show no matter what ! ! ! ! ! ! ! !
review: The movie may be "hypocritical Bullshit", however Keanu steals the deal like always. His style is unmatched, "punchlines are awesome". He made the crap look like an authentic relic. Anyways it was just another derivation from a comic book "Hellblazer" which allows it to create any possibility for the real world. Well most of us do believe in Heaven and Hell, so whats the fact that the movie isn't great. Ideally some hype is given to any movie that is made out of the comic book character profile..............well to name Spiderman......who is my favorite superhero "too"..........is a major hype too. however we all relished it didn't we...........I'm sure there are thousands of people who really liked the movie but trying to deny the fact that such thing can happen in the real world. Well just try concentrating on Keanu a bit.....put yourself in his shoes...........what would you do............how do you like the movie now. By the way just imagine Keanu doesn't go ahead and sign any crap unless and until he believes in it himself..............so all you Keanu geeks come up and agree that the movie is actually cool.

title: good if u like god,hell,demons,angels and other occult flicks
review: I loved how they made this movie with god in it, odd to say for a Keanu Reeves film, but the ending, how they made Satan seem god was well done, no one could do it better, you will have to watch this movie to see for yourself , comments don't work for this movie, i understand Keanu Reeves isn't the best actor but this is his role, but he doesn't look like Constantine from the Hellblazer comics, What they need is the guy who played iceman in X2 with a trench coat and tie to play him, brown trench coat red tie, Rachel Weiss was okay, Tilda Swinson did good as an angel, and the actor who played Satan was good, overall result, 50% like it 50% hate it, you will hear both sides, see it for yourself.

title: Wow, I Actually Liked It
review: This movie was a great surprise. I can't stand Keanu (canoe) Reeves and figured it would be an overly CGI'd "soft" Hollywood horror movie. First off, it's beautiful to look at and flows visually very well. The director, Frances Lawrence also has been a pleasant surprise. Usually when you hear a music video director is doing his first feature you can't help feel fear as to how music video like the movie will turn out. For a movie about Heaven and Hell and fighting demons he shows tasteful restraint and always stays true to his darker characters and the somber atmosphere. I even liked Ted, Uh, I mean Keanu. His persona was perfect for this character and the whoa dude factor is non-existent in his delivery. I also liked that they don't explain every damn thing about how he does what he does. The dialog is also restrained and there's no overly played one-liners or catch phrases. Also the "annoying" sidekick disappears for most of the movie and when he reappears he's actually enjoyable as they allow him to be 3-dimensional. His outcome is also refreshing as most Hollywood movies wouldn't actually go where his character ends up. Overall I enjoyed this movie a lot and fans of Keanu will love it but for me who is the opposite I found it well done with every aspect of the look, the score and the characters. I hope there's a sequel with the same team.

title: Not as bad as everyone says!
review: Constantine is a comic book based film which shows John constantine, a supernatural detective, who has been to hell before, and can detect demons, trying to solve why Isabel Dodson(weisz) committed suicide. Dodson has a twin sister, Angela Dodson who is a policewoman (also played by Weisz). The film is definitely not the worst superhero movie, but its not the greatest either. I liked it more than The Hulk or Blade movies. I thought the special effects were great, had some good direction and cinematography, the screenplay was a bit lacking as were some of the performances. My favorite in this film was Djimon Hounsou, who although wasn't his best, still gave the best performance of the film for me. Keanu Reeves was only decent in the lead, in a performance very similar to his work in matrix series. Tilda Swinton was a bit wasted to me, while Rachel Weisz was good in my eyes, I like her much more than most peopled o. Also Shia Labeouf is going to be a star soon (if he isn't considered one already), he had some pretty good scenes. Overall this film was entertaining, had some flaws, some good acting, but for the most part i call it a "one-timer", good movie though. 8/10 #269 on my list of all-timr favorite films

title: This is for all who actually liked the movie...
review: First of all,I wanted to write this because so many users have used this space for telling how bad Keanu Reeves and the movie was. I haven't read any of the comics but why you always have to compare the movie with the comics? Let the comics be one side of the story and the movie one side,each one has their own view. And as for Keanu,it sounds like all the comments that are posted here from the users,dislike Keanu already and is has nothing to do with this movie. So what amazes me is how come you have decided to watch the movie if you already hate the guy? I,myself like him and I think he was perfect for the role,he has his own kind charisma he can bring into his roles that fits perfectly in a story like this. The movie itself captured the spirit and mood accordingly for this kind of story and for my surprise,it had even some plot twists waiting around the corner. Conclusion,pure joy to watch all alone at night in your DVD and just enjoy...nine out of ten from me..

title: The Salvation of 'Constantine'.(my response to hard hearted comments)
review:
When I went to see this movie, I was captivated from start to finish. And when I left the theater, I found myself thinking about the movie and replaying many of the scenes and lines over and over again in my head for about the next 4 to 5 days. (wich is something that a movie hasn't done to me in quite a while) But I guess it all comes down to a few key factors that will decide if someone will like this movie or not.

Key factor#1: Bias expectations of die-hard 'HellBlazer' comic book fans.

It is true that there is a great deal of difference between the portrayals of the comic book and the movie. So as a result, any Hellblazer fan can be very disappointed after seeing this movie. However, these fans need to realize that the differences between the movie and the comic are intentional due to the fact that the writers of the 'HellBlazer' comic books where there the whole time the script and screen play were being written. In fact, they even contributed to it. I'm also sure that they weren't kicking and screaming in disappointment when Keanu Reaves was cast for the leading role. When I went to see the movie, I had never read a single 'HellBlazer' comic in my life, let alone being aware of them even existing, and as a result of this I was able to truly appreciate the move in its entirety. 'HellBlazer' fans probably don't have this advantage because after reading enough issues of the comics, the standard has already been set for the characters and story lines. Now of course the movie did peek my interest enough to pick up a few issues of 'HellBlazer' and actually read them. And even though there was a difference between the comic and the movie, I can't honestly say that the comic is better than the movie or vice-versa. I think thats what the writers and director was aiming for when making this film. They knew that the 'HellBlazer' comics don't have much awareness among comic readers as well as not very many fans. They wanted this movie to actually give the viewers enough interest to actually want to go and read at least one issue of 'HellBlazder'. So lets be real with ourselves here...(and this means all you 'HelBlazer' fans out there) if they wanted to keep the movie as close to the comic as they could, then they would have cast Hugh Jackman (wolverine in 'X-Men') for the role of 'John Constantine', dyed his hair dirty blonde, and given it the title "HellBlazer". But that's not what they did at all. I'm sure the title "Constantine" was chosen for more reasons other than "it sounds cool". Obviously the change in titles is to imply change in story line and characters. Plus not to mention the odd advertisement that states: "Loosely based on the 'HellBlazer' comic series". (Gee....I wonder what the key word in that statement was?)

Key factor#2: Are you or Aren't you a spiritual person?

I myself have read most of the Bible and believe entirely in it. My mother has an extreme catholic background and I also have a fascination and appreciation for Cathollasism. (although I am against religion as a politic and more for a charismatic belief in God and Christ) Now because of all the reading and studying and research that I've done for myself on the Bible, religion, doctrines, and spiritual things, I am able to say that the script and story line is very accurate and well written. As an example, I read a comment where the writer said that the angel Gabriel in the movie was lame and "looked like some sort of cross dresser". Well that is because there is religious doctrine that states that angels of God are not of any gender. They are neither male nor female. Hence, the angel Gabriel in the movie is hard to tell from male of female. (allthough the role is played by a female) So with that being said, anyone who has or is willing to acquire some knowledge of various religious doctrines, (particularly catholic belief's and the Bible in general) will most likely get a lot out of this movie.

Now to sum it all up on more of a movie-ish note.....I think that this was the best performance of Keanu's career, and not to mention Gavin Rosedales performance was flawless. Weizes performance lacked a little, but not enough to ruin the film. And the special effects were amazing. But most importantly, if you haven't seen this movie and are planning on it, pay attention to the performance give by the actor playing the part of Satan. This by far was the best and greatest performance of the movie. I don't know where they found this actor, but he does the part perfect. I would definitely like to see what other roles he is capable of doing.

But anyway....I've said enough already. Thanks for reading and if your planning on seeing this movie, enjoy ;)

Also...if you found this at all helpful and your curious about other movies that you're unsure of paying to see, send me an email. I'd love to hear from you and there's a good chance I've seen it.

Later ;)

title: I know everyone else hated it, BUT...
review:
Look. I used to be a die-hard comic fan. I know how INTENSE all you kids are looking for your comic book movies to be...but Christ! LOOK how awful Daredevil was! If you liked the original Superman movie w/Christopher Reeve...and if you liked the FIRST (and only, as far as I'm concerned) Crow movie, and IF you liked the most recent installment of Batman (circa Batman Begins)...give the rest of us a break, 'eh? Yes, Tim Burton's Batmans were above and beyond the rest of the CRAP that Joel Schumacher dared to release. Yes, Superman 1 and 2 beat the hell out of the rest of the franchise, and yes, only one Crow movie truly exists to us hardcore fans. But come ON! Tilda Swinton is a GENIUS in Constantine! She's a genius in EVERYTHING she does, all the way back to Orlando, as far as I'm concerned. Her role here in Constantine is no less impressive as Gabriel, and even Keanu moved me as the tortured soul who isn't ready to submit to Hell even as he battles the earthly confinements that refuse to relinquish his soul one way or the other.

Give Hollywood a break on this one, kids...did you NOT jump out of your seat in that opening scene w/the knife and the immigrant when he gets hit by the car? That's good stuff!!!!! Rag all you want, but this is FAR from the worst comic book adaptation done thus farly...in fact, I call it highly imaginative (despite the spider in the glass error), and the demons gave me nightmares several nights in a row. I call that...progress!!!! Personally can't wait until this comes out on DVD, and if you want something worse than this, watch ANY Wes Craven movie, or Freddie movie, or Jason or Michael movie...HO HUM. Old and tired and boring. At LEAST Constantine offers a fresh perspective on the fairy tale tip...when's the last time YOU saw dragon's breath in a film? Screw you guys...I LIKED this movie.

title: really nice!!!!
review: i think i saw this movie 3 times in only one month! i was totally impressed!!! i think it is one of the best movies on this topic....demons, angels, devil, hell, heaven and stuff like that! i really enjoyed it for a lot of reasons!!! one: the script is really good, they don't tell you everything, after the movie ends you have to sit back and think about certain stuff that wasn't really clear and believe me you'll get to some wild conclusions!! two: it has a really mysterious and dark atmosphere, it's unlike anything you've ever seen, it gives you the creeps and you just can't take your eyes away from the TV!!! i mean really!!! three: great special effects!!! four: great acting and last but not least five: NO KISSING!!!!!! OAU..that's a new one!!! overall great movie, extremely interesting, it really makes you put yourself a lot of questions and finally something original, nothing ordinary in it and extremely interesting.

title: Another "unfulfilled potential" movie
review: I wanted to like Constantine so much. Given its subject matter (which I'm interested in) and given that although I don't think Keanu Reeves is Laurence Olivier when it comes to acting I still find a way to like his performances, I did overall like this movie. But having said that it is just one more film that is in many ways an extended pop video of ideas - a 3 minute fix or head-rush rather than a thought out, subtle and nuanced piece of work. The basic story, of course, is ridiculous. It seems that most makers of popular films today, when dealing with theological issues, reduce them to magic or fable. Thus the "Spear of Destiny" (the one which pierced the side of Jesus in the Gospels) is reduced to an icon of magical power which makes the holder superhuman (the opening 2 minutes is excellent for impact in this respect, however). Quite why this spear has such power is a moot point at best. Further, it is taken for granted that angels and demons walk among us and that "witch doctors" wield real power. Of course, people will say this is all the stuff of story and we are supposed to suspend our disbelief. Indeed, we are. But we still need to believe something in our disbelief and this film, I repeat more extended pop video of ideas, is lacking a little in coherence. This film does not make you want to believe its own story which is always going to be a problem (and the Gabriel twist is the worst thing of all in this respect). I was waiting for the meat, the little something extra that makes a good film a stand out one. It never arrived. And then there is the Keanu factor. You look at Reeves and you see Neo. And Constantine is a lesser film than the Matrix Trilogy. Future casting directors should, I think, beware of casting Reeves if their movie is in a similar vein to The Matrix films. Inevitably, they will seem lesser films by comparison. Now there's a challenge!

title: Great Movie ! - trust me
review:
I really don't know what all these bad reviews are about. It almost looks like a 'Bashing Constantine' contest. Until now ... Ready? To me Constantine is the BEST MOVIE OF 2005 (so far). To clarify let me just break it down for you.

FX - brilliant, especially the hell scenes!

STORY - very creative and different with a nice twist at the end

ACTING - good performances by all the actors (Reeves, Hounsou and Stormare were especially great)

If you like movies like 'Dogma' or 'the Prophecy' you should go rent the DVD and enjoy this modern classic.

That's it. - 10 out of 10

title: "Woah..."
review: On the whole, this film left me with a "Eh, it was cool, I guess." feeling as I walked out of the theater. We all know Keanu Reeves isn't exactly praised for his acting abilities, unless he's starring in such films pertaining to the Matrix, so it's no surprised that I ended up disliking his performance in this one. More often than not I found myself laughing inside when he would deliver such a line that reminded me of his days as Ted Logan from Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventures. Despite his lack luster performance, and the occasional bad CGI trip, this film does hold some good. I liked the storyline, I thought Rachel Wiesz was fantastic, and I enjoyed the magic wand containing dragon's breath. (now if only there was a way to get my hands on that...) 6/10

title: Be a good Christian, be saved, don't smoke, but always carry a cross shaped gun with you
review: Awful heap of commonplaces about religion in an outrageously stupid display of the usual not so special effects. The worst of typical state of the art Hollywood crap. Ignoble attempt to conform to today's indisputable creed: smoking is dangerous always and without exceptions and the smoker is not only condemned to die, but damned to die forever. As Alexander Pope wrote in immortal words "fools rush in where angels fear to tread". Leave this piece of trashy propaganda to brain washed morons and save the money to buy a good pack of cigarettes. OK, this is based on comic books, shouldn't be taken seriously. so why bother, don't take it seriously. Don't even take it. Just omit it. It'll be useful time saved to see a good movie. If you give it a try you'll find there are millions better than this. Spoiler: chewing gum can damage your dentist's work and consequently your finances. Don't do it.

title: Entertaining fiction. Don't look for much more.
review:
I've read some posts about Constantine, saying that the plot is weak, insulting to the religious and so on. Since I've seen many trashing reviews, I am going to say something good about the movie to maintain "the balance".

The movie takes us into a world of demons and angels and shows a man who can interact with them working as an exorcist. The evolving plot is pure fun. It is full of twists, surprises and manages to be unpredictable until the very end. To someone familiar with the comic books or similar literature this might be different.

The acting in this movie has been often said to be poor, but... come on, this is a demon fighting movie. If you want to see acting, go to a drama theater. As for Keanu Reeves, I think he wasn't the best pick for this role. He seems to be a more fragile type of guy than Constantine and the rude attitude didn't really sell. The performance of Rachel Weisz has been glorified, but as I said, why do you have to look for acting in this kind of movie?

The special effects aren't stunning, but they also don't seem to lack anything and complement the plot fairly. I specially enjoyed the "theme park of fire".

Watch this movie if you want shallow entertainment, but don't expect anything meaningful. Just because it has angels and demons, doesn't mean it addresses religious issues - it doesn't.

Lastly, if you've seen this movie, be sure to watch South Park's episode Best Friends Forever (904). They do a great job in making fun of this movie.

title: Something a bit different!
review:
I went to see Constantine with a few friends last night. None of us knew the storyline, or anything about the film, except that it was about heaven and hell.

We all found this film to be surprisingly good and a bit of a change to the over-hyped 'hollywood blockbusters' (half of which are rubbish) that we had been seeing lately. None of us could predict what was coming next (although you had a feeling as to what the result of the film would be). You do have to listen to it, otherwise you will miss the odd few lines which explain the film! However, the effects and storyline were good.

It was certainly a damn sight better than the last film we saw at the cinema (Elektra!!).

title: Letter to the producers of Constantine
review:
Dear Producers of Constantine: I thought you would like to know that my husband and I went to see your movie last night at our local flea pit. The audience (including us) totaled four. For our local flea pit on a Saturday night, that's a great turnout (we were the only people in the audience for a Saturday night showing of Lost in Translation.) Anyway, I have to say that my husband fell asleep after the first half hour. And he's a CGI fan.

Constantine isn't all bad. The CGI is very, very good (The Hell scene looked cheap on a "Constantine: The Movie" TV special we caught, but it was impressive on the semi big screen of the fleapit). The art direction is fabulous. The guy who played Satan was a knockout. His scene with him sparring on a chair while Keanu tries to light up came the closest to the comic. The costuming was like the script: everything was in black and white.

If you're going to base a movie on a very cool ironic comic with a big fan base, why didn't you first of all stick to the comic? John Constantine Hellblazer the comic character kicks wacko demons' butts. Why did you give the green light to a script that featured a uber Catholic morality tale? (I heard Jamie Delano and Garth Ennis, both writers for Hellblazer the comic, took their names off the film. What happened to their treatment?) I knew the film was going to be a stinker when I heard Keanu was a playing an American John Constantine and the setting was Los Angeles. The location people did a great job in finding creepy buildings and streets to shoot, but Los Angeles? For Constantine? Having an American actor play a British character, given a good script, may not be such a disaster, but why put the character in a setting that doesn't evoke the comic at all? And why did you put an amoral sorcerer who smokes like a chimney in a plot complete with anti smoking propaganda? The most unbelievable part of the film was Constantine looking over the skyline at the end and popping gum in his mouth. The coda of him putting his lighter on the tombstone of his sidekick was even worse.

I can't blame Keanu for turning in a blank performance because the writers gave him nothing to work with. Rachel Weise's performance was amazing given that she didn't have much to do in her part either except get wet and look scared a lot. The supporting characters were twitchy like the comic would have them but also too twitchy- maybe they just seem OTT compared to Keanu's vapidness. The best performance by far was the cat's. He had the best written part.

I can see your wanting to promote Vertigo titles  Warner Brothers owns DC comics  but next time you make an adaptation, get a writer who has worked on the comics. Or at least knows the comics. And please don't try to add messages based on public service commercials.

title: Constantine is the Max Payne of heaven and hell!
review:
Constantine is the Max Payne of heaven and hell... yeah, thats right. Keanu plays the role of a man that is haunted and blessed by god in this movie where the classic struggle between good and evil are blown out of proportions.

Even though I am not a fan of movies that originally is a comic I have to say that this one is really well done. I haven't read the comic though. Maby the movie would be horrible if I had. But, since I haven't read it I can safely say that I really liked the movie.

I have to warn everyone that hate religion though. This movie is heavily based on Satan and God as they are known through the bible. And if you are all against that I believe that you will find this movie a bit boring. Other than that there should not be any worries. It offers all that a classic action movie should give you. A high paced plot line with cool effects and a genuine hero. Don't expect any miracles though, its just a movie...

title: Keanu Reeves is such a great actor
review: 'Constantine', a film based on some comic books I've never read because I lost my virginity long ago, stars one of our finest thespians, Keanu Reeves, as an exorcist. For the duration of the film, Keanu gets into all kinds of crazy adventures with weird demons and other evildoers. There are plenty of scenes involving hideous creatures trying to force their way out from underneath peoples' skin, scenes that look like nu-metal videos, and other crap like that. Anyway, Keanu performs some exorcisms, holds some chick underwater in a bathtub so she can magically go back and see some other chick's suicide firsthand, the singer from Bush shows up for some reason (I'm surprised I recognized him...it's been what, 10 years or so since MTV and corporate rock radio were torturing me with that crappy band?) and a bunch of other stuff happens. I don't really remember what happens or why, because I was barely paying attention, and I got up and took a stroll around the big, fancy concession area for about 10 minutes or so when I noticed my friend had fallen asleep. I was also preoccupied with the popcorn I was eating, which was absolutely delicious. I've had a lot of different kinds of popcorn, but none can compare to what's offered at my local Loews' multiplex. Anyway, right after I got back, a group of about 7 kids seated behind me decided they just weren't man enough to endure the remainder of 'Constantine', and they walked out. I wanted to wake my friend up and ask if he wanted to follow suit, but I didn't want to be rude. I hate when people wake me up out of my sleep. Anyway, in the end, Keanu prevails (I'm pretty sure). He might get the girl, but I don't really remember. Sadly, his sidekick/comic foil Shia LaBoeuf, does not survive. 2/10, just because I've seen worse.

title: Not for hard core, unbending fan boys
review:
or for those unwilling to let a couple of things slip. Or those who require everything tiny thing explained, and cant just let not having it so go.

I wasn't expecting much when i entered the theatre to see Constantine, although having read the hell blazer comics i was looking forward to seeing how they portrayed the deep dark character of John Constantine - which i think they did particularly well - on screen.

As the plot develops we are introduced slowly to the character of Angela, played wondrously by Rachel weisz, and john Constantine, played surprisingly well by Keanu reeves. The camera pans back to reveal great performances by the likes of Shia Labeouf, who at first appears to play the arch-typical annoying sidekick character, but turns out to be a great addition to the cast, and the half-breeds, namely Balthazar and the delectable Gabriel. These surprisingly... interesting and 'deep' (And in Balthazar's case camp! :) ) - if you are willing to suspend the theology lesson for an hour or two- characters deliver fantastic performances and drive the plot on its merry way in a brilliant fashion.

The humour throughout is dark and honest; currently one of John's most repeated lines is 'A mental patient killing herself? Now that's just crazy'. Nothing is pulled when it comes to depicting the darker moodier side of the characters natures.

Throughout the movie the audience are expected to think a bit more for themselves on occasions. The screenplay writers have been innovative in their work - not sticking with the traditional 'garlic kills this, sunlight kills that' - yet they have seen fit not to use the traditional five minute explanation as to why it would work. For those who are wondering why a mirror would work (Tee hee, go see it, you'll understand ;) ) why does it matter? what is there to stop anything new from working in this world? Alongside infuriating pedants i would not recommend this movie to hardcore fan boys expecting exactly what the comics deliver, its a work very much inspired by Hellblazer. Which is exactly why it was called 'Constantine' instead of just 'Hellblazer'. It has taken the Character and Ideas.

As with any movie, some will love it, some will hate it, some will laugh. The comic adaptations have been booming lately and i would place this one amongst the few, such as hell boy, who are doing their origins justice. Not only does it do that, I think it does so without having to mimic the subject matter. The writers, actors, CGI weird monster things have put damn near their all in this.

And id like to take this chance to thank the costume designers for putting Gabriel in that outfit... (Dribble)

title: Good Occult Thriller
review:
For the record I have read Hellblazer, the source of this film, and I do like the comic.

Also for the record I do like this movie a great deal as well.

Is it the comic? Thats open to debate. I think in many ways it it is. I think the problem is that they've made a film about a very complex character who's been developed over hundreds of issues and distilled him down to what a mass audience could take in.(remember this is a character that runs in DC's alternative, non "mainstream" Vertigo comic line) No, he's not English, its not set in London, and its not always night and raining, but other than that I think they have the feel. Keanu for my money is pretty good. I think the problem for most people who read the comic is he's not a snarky Brit and therefore its not Constantine. I think he's fine and his performance takes other bits of his personality and brings them to the forefront. Its no different than the way different writers have handled the character over the years.

As a movie its a very good. Its not high art and its not Silence of the Lambs scary, but its a really good thriller with neat visuals and a creepy attitude. Any movie that can keep me up and awake until almost two in the morning when going in I could barely keep my eyes open, has to be a very good film.

I must single several of the supporting cast, Tilda Swinton as Gabriel and Peter Stormare as Satan. Both give great performances, though Storemare's devil who desperately wants Constantine's soul is flesh crawling evil at its finest. Talk about evil incarnate.

The plot has to do with the "re-discovery" of the Spear of Destiny, the attempt of the son of Satan to take over the world, and the investigation of the supposed suicide of an LA detectives twin sister. Its not giving anything away to say they are all related nor that there intertwining forms a pretty dark path.

This is a really good movie thats worth seeing if you're into ghoulies and ghosties and things that bump in the night.

title: Very well done movie, worth of watching and enjoyable
review:
Well Pretty GOOD.

I enjoyed a lot. First of all I haven't even seen comic. So I really had no knowledge about the original plot. now, I liked script and dare to say those who don't like it PROBABLY are those who are under impression of comic.

It's a strange thing: American movie-goers never complain about when movie has different plot then a book or is quite different from historical facts, but if you make a movie on Comic and it is not what they expect they start whining. Why? Gladiator or Cleopatra or Troy are totally different then what was really happening or what should happen, but no complaints were made.

Here is a big discussion if Keeanu is Constantine or not. Why those who don't like him expect Constantine of movie to be what they have read in book? Achiless of Troy is not exactly of Achiless of Homer but who says anything? nobody.

So what' wrong with script? nothing. Pretty well made.

Now about other stuff: Acting: great. Directing: awesome. Special effects? 10 out of 10.

Well worth of my time and money.

title: Worth Watching
review:
I enjoyed this movie immensely. I did not find myself looking at my watch or fidgeting in my seat waiting for the film to either move on or end.

I have not read the comic book, so I can not comment how well it did or did not keep to the original story line. The movie uses the fairly traditional good versus evil plot, with the hero having to be one whether he likes it or not. It has been done before, but I found this movie to be somewhat refreshing in comparison to everything else out there.

The supporting cast is colorful and likable. In general, they are used effectively to keep the movie going through their interactions with Reeve's character Constantine. I do think they should have used Shia LaBeouf's character Chas Chandler a little more, but for some reason he seems to vanish at certain points in the movie. Maybe these scenes were left on the cutting room floor to keep the movie condensed and at a reasonable length without killing it.

I did feel some Matrix-like influences on this movie, in the tone, scene site selections, and some of the special effects. But have faith, this movie is not Constantine meets the Matrix. But if you liked the Matrix, regardless of whether you hated Revolutions and Reloaded, I think you will enjoy this movie. It doesn't have the overbearing symbolism or the deafening soundtrack.

If you're a fan of Sci-Fi/Fantasy, Comic Books, the Matrix, or other items along that genre you will hate or love this film. For the casual fan, I think if you want to watch a movie that you will be entertained by I think this is a good choice versus a lot of the other garbage being released today.

But, as always, in the end. Its up to each and every viewer to decide.

title: If you like action and fantasy, this movie is for you!
review:
"Constantine" is a action packed, Heaven vs. Hell movie which is filled with uncountable special effects scenes which were all done perfectly. Although the movie is very fast paced and if you blink for a moment you'll miss an important part, it left me very satisfied and I'll most definitely see it again.

Although many seem to think Reeves' performance was less than acceptable, I found his brooding hero persona to be both convincing and nicely done. I'd definitely say that this is my favourite performance of his so far.

Weisz herself seemed to jump from the screen into our hearts, giving an excellent performance throughout the whole film and playing her part perfectly.

I personally loved this movie, but I haven't read the comics, and am therefor not enraged at the differences, and I also love action-fantasy movies much like this.

I'd recommend this to anyone who wouldn't be personally offended by Comic-book differences and wants to see Reeves and Weisz at their best.

title: I would see it again...
review:
For a movie that so many file in the "comic book" movie genre, Constantine exceeded my expectations and is an excellent piece of entertainment, in spite of being amidst the "dumpers" that usually are put out in the month of February.

The graphics, camera work, and animation were excellent, but didn't ultimately become the entertainment value of the movie, which I consider an excellent feat for movies of this genre. The plot made me want to know more, and the acting was good. The writing wasn't excellent, per se, but didn't have me leaving the movie thinking, "Why do people pay millions of dollars to writers when I could write a better script?" like many other comic book movies have had me screaming. Still, having not read the comic books, I should also say that I cannot comment on the movie's ability to maintain consistency with the author's work.

Overall, you can take as much away from this movie as you want. If you're looking for entertainment, this movie has it in spades. If you're looking for an interesting story, with implications on the greater picture, you can definitely take that away from this movie, too. Personally, I thought it was great  despite what many other critics have written, and I would go and see it again.

Oh! And definitely stay past the credits!

title: Great flick
review: Just wanted to say that this is a great flick and that I recommend it to any sci fi fan out there. The only negative comment I have to make about the movie is that the pacing is a little off. This leads to some dull moments. I can assure you that there aren't many. The main plot was excellent with some pretty good humor mixed in ver nicely. Dexpite what a lot of people have said I fell that Keanu Reeves did any excellent job in portraying Constantine. His supporting cast was superb as well. The special effects were a very delightful surprise. I was very concerned going into the movie that they were going to be rather hokey. Definitely NOT. That was some of the best that I have seen to date. They also did not over do it. You were always left wanting more.

title: My God, it's not bad.
review:
I walked into Constantine with rock bottom expectations. It's a February release, which usually hints that the studio is not confident in the film. It's a comic book movie, and unlike the good ones of the last few years, it strays from the source material. And of course it stars the old oak bloke himself, Keanus Reeves.

That said, the movie is actually pretty good. Despite it's R rating, one should not expect a serious horror movie in the traditional sense. This is a comic book movie, with overblown cgi and slo-mo battle sequences. I say overblown cgi, but I was actually impressed with the restraint the director showed in this sense. The movie is propelled mostly through dialogue, and it helps that most of the characters are well cast.

Tilda Swinton was the perfect choice to play the ambiguous angel, and Peter Stormare as Satan was an inspired decision. However, Keanu Reeves as the chain smoking cancer stricken Exorcist is the key performance, and the best. It is truly a revelation to Reeves fit so snugly into this role, for the first time I could not imagine him saying 'Whoa'. I've heard his performance likened to a modern day Shatner or Heston, and I think that's accurate. I am please to see that Reeves has finally found his calling as an actor, after being wasted over the years on romantic comedies and the Matrix sequels (He was pretty good as a man discovering the truth about the world and his role in saving it in the original Matrix, but I don't think he pulled off the part of the messiah in action in the latter two.) and here he really shines.

The script is above average at best, but the moody sets, pacing, and Reeves' performance keep it from burning in the same fires as 'Elektra'.

title: Keanu is his good old Matrixy self
review:
Constantine is really more about the guys behind the camera than what's going on in front of it. There's some awesome cinematography that will appeal to anyone with a taste for darker movies. There's some tasteful use of unusually-angled camera angles that actually add to the film, and some really smooth depictions of hell and demons. Some of the special effects really are mindblowing.

But, you can't help feel that this Keanu is just a slightly more spiritual version of Neo from the Matrix - the role doesn't stretch him much, and he spends a lot of time playing his character a little too deadpan and emotionless for one supposedly so conflicted.

The story itself has an interesting plot to it (probably better than most comic book-based movies) but is detracted from by some truly awful clichéd lines scattered throughout the movie. The end was disappointing too - it really wasn't wrapped up well.

So all in all, yeah, it's a good movie to go watch, but just don't go in expecting a masterpiece.

title: Worth the POA..
review:
If you're someone who spends/spent more time in church chewing gum and looking at girls outfits rather than actually trying to decipher a sermon, then you'll find the movie quite fascinating I think...

Tales of war between God and Satan, good vs evil, man they are as old as time...But the addition of a rather mysterious artifact coupled with mythic and powerful creatures stirring right about our nests in a way I haven't quite seen it done before in a film was awesome...It Does what a good movie is supposed to do, give you guidance to some questions, while at the same time creating new ones...

I found this movie to be entertaining without being shallow, shedding light into some aspects, but not too much...An awesome film, especially if you're a fan of occult artifacts and lore...Probably won't be understood until the DVD comes out in all honesty, but still a good film...

AYHJA, www.AYHJA.net

title: Does what it is supposed to do quite nicely.
review:
I've noticed a trend in the reviews of those who really loathed this movie. They are either big fans of the comic, or they really hate Keanu Reeves. Well, Keanu isn't going to be winning any Oscars, but his performance is certainly one of his best, and he has an excellent supporting cast, as well as great cinematography and set pieces, to nurse him along.

To be succinct, this movie is an absolute hoot. Its version of hell is without a doubt the most creative and frightening I've seen in a movie. The many visual effects help instead of distract.

The best thing about the movie? It was a REAL "good vs. evil" story. The good was righteous, and the evil was reprehensible and vile. Peter Stormare is really a fantastically good (which means bad) Satan.

The worst thing about the movie? The inexplicable "holy shotgun". It is a gold-painted gaudy monstrosity, which looks about as dangerous as a super soaker. The gunfight was pretty well filmed, so couldn't they at least have given the man something other than the sissy pistol? A normal shotgun with holy shells would have been much better.

In conclusion, if you want a very good, entertaining movie, with some genuinely chilling moments, great characters, and an interesting plot, go see this one. If you want the comic books, stay home and read them. If you hate Keanu, just hush. We already know he's not Deniro, so live with it.

For what it does, I give it 8/10 and will buy it on DVD when it comes out.

TheMonk

title: "Matrix" meets "Blade" meets "Devil's Advocate"
review: Just went to see "Constantine" this afternoon. My initial impression was that it seemed very much like a "Blade" type movie (instead of vampires, you have demons). Similar weapons are used here and seem as if they could be used in either movie. No Kung Fu or martial arts here though. This movie for me also seems like a collage of what Keanu has done in previous movies. Reeves character is very much like Neo from the "Matrix"; brooding and conflicted messiah-like. There's's a similar storyline with him on a reluctant mission to save the world and ultimately himself. The final confrontation scene has a similar feel to when Keanu's character in the "Devil's Advocate" meets Al Pacino/the devil and he reveals his true identity, though the actor playing Lucifer here doesn't compare with Pacino's performance. The movie is entertaining and thought-provoking but the plot is somewhat confusing and hard to follow at times. I Don't suggest going for popcorn or the bathroom during it because you'll probably be lost or confused on what's going on (maybe if I had been familiar with the comics it would have helped in following the story better). So that's why I give a rating of 6.

title: A horror film with somewhere to go.
review:
Jonah Goldberg, editor at large of National Review OnLine, recently wrote that "we couldn't appreciate that evil is real and it exists. In a society where everyone is a victim and it's not right to 'judge' others, there's not much room left for real monsters, while society itself becomes monstrous." And so Hannibal Lecter is a "charming rogue" rather than a monster.

A new paranormal action thriller, Constantine, brings us back to the days of discernible demons. An old Catholic boy like me truly enjoys any struggle between good and evil that features luminaries such as Lucifer, Balthazar, and Gabriel. Have minimalist actor Keanu Reeves play a supernatural detective with echoes of Matrix's Neo and the talented Tilda Swinton (The Deep End) a genderless Angel Gabriel and you have a horror film with somewhere to go, to Hades that is. These are monsters and angels I can see and love and hate and most of all, call them what they are.

Reeves' lung-cancer-terminal John Constantine is from the Hellblazer comic book, a bad boy sleuth who has literally been to Hell and now chases half-breed Hell denizens back to where they belong so that he might win his way to heaven. His partner, Angela Dodson (Rachel Weisz), tags along to find out why her twin sister committed suicide in circumstances that have hellish affiliations. Beyond this summary lies a convoluted story about Constantine's attempts to keep a balance between heaven and hell that stops long enough for us to enjoy an over-the-top visit from white-clad Satan, played with obvious delight by Peter Stormare (Minority Report).

The f/x is as impressive as any horror/thriller's out there today, and Reeves' performance is as one note as we have come to expect. His clothes, thanks to Louise Frogley's monochromatic costuming, are slick black, a complement to the noirish world of black and white. (For you purists, the comic book hero is made into a Los Angeles native allegedly because Reeves couldn't be counted on to keep a proper Brit accent for over two hours).
